NOTICE TO THE PARTIES - The Court is participating in the Mandatory Initial Discovery Pilot (MIDP) and this case is subject to that pilot. The key features and deadlines are set forth in the attached Notice which includes General Order 17-08. Also attached is a checklist for use by the parties. All parties must respond to the mandatory initial discovery requests set forth in the General Order before initiating any further discovery in this case. Please note: The discovery obligations in the General Order supersede the disclosures required by Rule 26(a)(1). Any party seeking affirmative relief must serve a copy of the attached documents (Notice to Parties, including General Order 17-08 and MIDP Checklist) on each new party when the Complaint, Counterclaim, Crossclaim, or Third-Party Complaint is served. (SIB) (Entered: 09/04/2018)

case_data.name: Puente v. Phoenix, City of
case_data.plaintiff_description: Five individuals who attended the August 22, 2017 protest outside of the Phoenix Convention Center, two Arizona nonprofits, and all persons who were also present at the protest who did not engage in any conduct justifying the defendants' use of gas and chemical agents against them.
case_data.summary:
On August 22, 2017, a group of protesters gathered outside the Phoenix Convention Center to protest a speech by President Donald Trump and voice disagreement with President Trump’s anti-immigrant policies and views. Over one year later, on September 4, 2018, five individuals who attended the protest and two Arizona nonprofits (“the plaintiffs”) brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the City of Phoenix, the Phoenix Chief of Police, and nine other officers with the Phoenix Police Department (PPD) (“the defendants”) alleging that the defendants violated the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution.

Specifically, the plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU of Arizona and private counsel, claimed that the defendants carried out an unannounced attack on the peaceful protesters on the night of August 22, 2017, using pepper spray, gas, pepper bullets, and flash-bang canisters. As such, the plaintiffs requested that the court grant them declaratory relief, a preliminary and permanent injunction prohibiting the defendants from engaging in any of the unconstitutional behaviors alleged in the complaint, monetary damage, and attorney’s fees.

In their complaint, the plaintiffs sought to represent themselves and also all persons who were present at the protest on August 22, 2017, who did not engage in any conduct justifying the defendants’ use of force against them. After over a year of litigation, Judge John J Tuchi granted in part and denied in part the plaintiffs’ motion to certify the class on September 30, 2019. The court certified the plaintiffs’ proposed subclass as to those individuals injured by gas and chemical agents, but denied certification as to those individuals injured by projectiles. 2019 WL 4849613.

After conducting discovery for another six months, the plaintiffs stipulated on May 6, 2020, to the dismissal from the case of three PPD officers named in the complaint as defendants. Shortly after, on May 8, 2020, both parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment. Two years later, on February 7, 2022, Judge Tuchi denied the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment, granted the defendants’ motion for summary judgment as to the plaintiffs’ class-wide claims, and granted in part and denied in part the defendants’ motion as to the plaintiffs’ individual claims. The court found both that the defendants did not seize the plaintiffs under the Fourth Amendment by deploying gas and chemical agents into the crowd of protesters, and that the defendants did not act with the purpose to harm the class members unrelated to legitimate law enforcement objectives or with the purpose to chill class members’ First Amendment rights. Accordingly, Judge Tuchi concluded that the defendants were entitled to qualified immunity for their actions with respect to the class members. 2022 WL 357351

Following Judge Tuchi’s February 7, 2022 order, the court set for trial the Fourth Amendment Excessive Force claims of three individual plaintiffs.

In response to the court’s decision, both the plaintiffs and defendants appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. As of June 5, 2022, these appeals are still pending and this case is ongoing.
case_data.summary_short:
On August 22, 2017, a group of protesters gathered outside the Phoenix Convention Center to protest a speech by President Donald Trump and voice its disagreement with President Trumpโs anti-immigrant policies and views. Over one year later, on September 4, 2018, five individuals who attended the protest and two Arizona nonprofits (โthe plaintiffsโ) brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the City of Phoenix, the Phoenix Chief of Police, and nine other officers with the Phoenix Police Department (PPD) (โthe defendantsโ) alleging that the defendants violated their rights under the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution by carrying out an unannounced attack on the peaceful protesters on the night of August 22, 2017, using pepper spray, gas, pepper bullets, and flash-bang canisters. In their complaint, the plaintiffs sought to represent themselves and also all persons who were present at the protest on August 22, 2017, who did not engage in any conduct justifying the defendantsโ use of force against them. On September 30, 2019, the court certified the plaintiffsโ proposed subclass as to those individuals injured by gas and chemical agents, but denied certification as to those individuals injured by projectiles.

On February 7, 2022 the court found both that the defendants did not seize the plaintiffs under the Fourth Amendment by deploying gas and chemical agents into the crowd of protesters, and that the defendants did not act with the purpose to harm the class members unrelated to legitimate law enforcement objectives or with the purpose to chill class membersโ First Amendment rights. Accordingly, Judge Tuchi concluded that the defendants were entitled to qualified immunity for their actions with respect to the class members, but set for trial the Fourth Amendment Excessive Force claims of three individual plaintiffs. In response to the courtโs decision, both the plaintiffs and defendants appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. As of June 5, 2022, these appeals are still pending and this case is ongoing.
case_data.summary_tiny: U.S. District Court judge found that police officers who deployed pepper spray, gas, pepper bullets, and flash-bang canisters against Trump protests on August 22, 2017, were entitled to qualified immunity (D. AZ).

documents.title: Order on Motion to Certify Class
documents.text:
1  WO 
2   
3   
4   
5   
6  IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
7  FOR THE DISTRICT OF ARIZONA 
 
8 
 
9  Puente, et al.,  No. CV-18-02778-PHX-JJT 
   
10  Plaintiffs,  ORDER  
   
11  v.  
 
12  City of Phoenix, et al., 
 
13  Defendants. 
14    At issue is Plaintiffsโ Amended Motion for Class Certification (Doc. 101, Mot.), to 
15  which  Defendants  filed  a  Response  (Doc.  113,  Resp.)  and  Plaintiffs  filed  a  Reply 
16  (Doc. 127, Reply). The Court heard oral argument on the Motion on June 12, 2019. 
17  (Docs. 160, 165.) In this Order, the Court will also resolve Defendantsโ Motion for Leave 
18  to Supplement the Class Certification Record (Doc. 138), Motion to File Exhibit under Seal 
19  (Doc. 141), and Motion for Leave to File a Sur-Reply (Doc. 144), as well as Plaintiffsโ 
20  Motion to Strike Portions of Defendantsโ Supplements or Alternatively for Leave to 
21  Respond to Defendantsโ Filings (Doc. 146). 
22  I.  BACKGROUND 
23  On  August  22,  2017,  President  Donald  Trump  held  a  rally  at  the  Phoenix 
24  Convention Center, and approximately 6,000 demonstratorsโboth pro-Trump and anti-
25  Trumpโgathered  outside  the  Convention  Center.1  The  Phoenix  Police  Department 
26 
                                              
1 The background facts summarized here are a synthesis of the partiesโ proffered video 
27 
evidence  (Doc.  90  Exs.  29โ39;  Resp.  Exs.  42โ64),  testimony,  and  reports.  Certain 
discrepancies exist within this evidence, but the Court is satisfied that its synthesis is 
28 
sufficiently accurate for the purpose of resolving Plaintiffsโ Amended Motion for Class 
Certification. 
 

 
 
 
 
1  (โPPDโ) had about a weekโs advance notice of the rally, during which it made preparations 
2  to try to ensure the safety of the downtown area during the expected demonstrations. The 
3  preparations  included  setting  up  a  โfree  speech  zoneโ  designated  for  anti-Trump 
4  demonstrators on the north side of the Convention Center, across Monroe Street. The free 
5  speech zone was bordered by 2nd Street to the west, 3rd Street to the east, and Monroe 
6  Street to the south, and demarcated by a three-foot high pedestrian fence. PPD anticipated 
7  that certain groups of demonstrators would be present, including  Antifaโa national, 
8  militant political protest movement opposing fascism and right-wing ideology  whose 
9  groups  had  disrupted  several  other  demonstrations  in  the  weeks  preceding  President 
10  Trumpโs Phoenix visitโas well as Plaintiff Puenteโa Phoenix grassroots organization 
11  representing  migrant  communities  through  lobbying,  advocacy,  and  activismโand 
12  Plaintiff Poder in Action (โPoderโ)โa Phoenix grassroots organization with a mission of 
13  empowering victims of injustice through leadership development, civic engagement, and 
14  policy advocacy. 
15    In  a  Presidential  Visit  After-Action  Report  (Doc.  101-3  at  2โ35,  Bates  Nos. 
16  COP014832โ014865, โPPD Reportโ), Defendant PPD Chief Jeri Williams stated that, on 
17  the day of the rally, PPD deployed approximately 985 officers around the Convention 
18  Center. According to the report, large crowds of demonstrators began arriving by 11:00 a.m. 
19  and, although PPD officers observed minor altercations and a few water bottles being 
20  thrown at rally attendees lining up to enter the Convention Center, the demonstrations 
21  proceeded generally without incident during the day. 
22  The rally inside the Convention Center began at 6:30 p.m. At approximately 8:15 
23  p.m., after PPD officers around 2nd Street and Monroe reported that water bottles were 
24  being thrown at them, PPD used a Long Range Acoustic Device (โLRADโ) to make 
25  announcements instructing individuals to stop throwing objects. At 8:23 p.m., 15 to 20 
26  individuals PPD had identified as Antifa put up large banners near the fence along Monroe, 
27  which concealed their activities from PPD officers. PPD deployed Tactical Response Unit 
28  (โTRUโ) personnel, including grenadiers trained in the deployment of chemical munitions, 
 
- 2 - 

 
 
 
 
1  in the area where Antifa had gathered. Just after 8:32 p.m., President Trump began to leave 
2  the rally, and PPD officers observed Antifa pushing or shaking the fence.  
3    PPD deployed its first munition in front of Antifa just before 8:33 p.m. in the form 
4  of pepper balls on the ground, which cleared most individuals from the immediate vicinity. 
5  Thereafter, PPD officers reported that rocks and bottles were being thrown and, at 8:34, 
6  officers reported that canisters of some kind of tear gas were thrown at them. At that point, 
7  PPD officers donned gas masks and, at 8:35, the grenadiers deployed inert smoke bombs. 
8  Large numbers of demonstrators began to clear the area.  
9  After officers noted that some smoke canisters were being kicked back and a spear-
10  like object and an incendiary device were thrown at them, the grenadiers deployed CS 
11  gasโa type of tear gasโin what they perceived to be a focused location to target specific 
12  individuals. Plaintiff Gonzalez Goodman alleges she inhaled gas. The grenadiers also 
13  deployed aerial flash bangs intended to act as auditory warnings. Demonstrators began to 
14  run away and, by 8:39, the area where individuals had been throwing projectiles was mostly 
15  empty, although demonstrators remained to the east and west of the area. 
16    From 8:36 to 8:45, PPD used additional smoke cannisters and pepper balls to clear 
17  an area so that officers could form lines to begin dispersing the crowd. Helicopters from 
18  the PPD Air Unit began arriving at 8:40, and they started making announcements directing 
19  the crowd to disperse at 8:52. In this time period, the grenadiers deployed smoke canisters, 
20  pepper balls, and OC bulletsโbullets filled with pepper sprayโone of which hit Plaintiff 
21  Guillen. Lines of PPD officers with riot shields began marching to move the crowd at 8:56. 
22  At some point between 8:42 and 8:47, PPD made the determination that the crowd was 
23  unlawfully assembled, and at 9:02, an official unlawful assembly announcement was made 
24  via a public address system from a marked police vehicle on the ground. 
25    Thereafter, the grenadiers deployed munitions in the form of pepper balls, OC 
26  bullets, and CS gas canisters at anyone who approached a police officer, and Plaintiff 
27  Travis was hit several times. PPD officers told the press to leave the area at 9:20 p.m. The 
28  crowd was dispersed and gone from the free speech area by 9:56 p.m.

16  II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
17  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(a) provides that a class actionโthat is, an action 
18  in which one or more members of a class sue on behalf of all members of the classโmay 
19  proceed only if four prerequisites are met: 
20  (1)  Numerosity:  โthe  class  is  so  numerous  that  joinder  of  all  members  is 
21  impracticable;โ 
22  (2)  Commonality: โthere are questions of law or fact common to the class;โ 
23  (3)  Typicality: โthe claims or defenses of the representative parties are typical of 
24  the claims or defenses of the class;โ and 
25  (4)  Adequacy  of  Representation:  โthe  representative  parties  will  fairly  and 
26  adequately protect the interests of the class.โ 
27  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a). 
28 
 
- 4 - 

 
 
 
 
1    In addition, under Rule 23(b), a court may only certify a class action if there is at 
2  least one of the following: 
3  (1)  Risk of Inconsistency: the prosecution of separate actions by individual class 
4  members would create a risk of inconsistent adjudications or adjudications 
5  that would be dispositive of non-party class member interests; or 
6  (2)  Appropriate Class-Wide Injunctive Relief: injunctive or declaratory relief is 
7  appropriate respecting the class as a whole because the conduct of  the 
8  opposing party applies generally to the class; or 
9  (3)  Predominance and Superiority: โthe court finds that the questions of law or 
10  fact common to class members predominate over any questions affecting 
11  only individual members, and that a class action is superior to other available 
12  methods for fairly and efficiently adjudicating the controversy.โ 
13  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b). 
14    โRule  23  does  not  set  forth  a  mere  pleading  standard.  A  party  seeking  class 
15  certification must affirmatively demonstrate his compliance with the Ruleโthat is, he must 
16  be prepared to prove that there are in fact sufficiently numerous parties, common questions 
17  of law or fact, etc.โ Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 564 U.S. 338, 350 (2011). Thus, 
18  โโsometimes it may be necessary for the court to probe behind the pleadings before coming 
19  to rest on the certification question.โโ Id. (quoting Gen. Tel. Co. of the Sw. v. Falcon, 457 
20  U.S. 147, 160 (1982)). Class certification โis proper only if โthe trial court is satisfied, after 
21  a rigorous analysis, that the prerequisites of Rule 23(a) have been satisfied,โโ which will 
22  frequently โentail some overlap with the merits of the plaintiffโs underlying claim.โ Id. at 
23  350โ51 (quoting Falcon, 457 U.S. at 161).

21      1.  Failsafe Class Definition 
22    Defendants argue that Plaintiffsโ proposed damages class definition fails, somewhat 
23  ironically, because it is โfailsafeโโthat is, it limits โmembership to plaintiffs described by 
24  their theory of liability in the class definition such that the definition presupposes success 
25  on the merits.โ Melgar v. CSK Auto, Inc., 681 F. Appโx 605, 607 (9th Cir. 2017). Put 
26  another way, Defendants argue that, by limiting class membership to those โwho did not 
27  engage in any conduct justifying the Defendantsโ use of force against them,โ the class

1  definition requires that the Court examine the merits of each individualโs claim before it 
2  can determine whether the individual is a member of the class, which Defendants contend 
3  is unacceptable. (Resp. at 12โ15.)  
4    As Defendants point out, โโDefining the class is of critical importance because it 
5  identifies the persons (1) entitled to relief, (2) bound by a final judgment, and (3) entitled 
6  under Rule 23(c)(2) to the best notice practicable in a Rule 23(b)(3) action.โ Thus, a class 
7  definition โmust be precise, objective, and presently ascertainableโ before a class action can 
8  proceed.โ (Resp. at 12 (quoting Daniel F. v. Blue Shield of Cal., 305 F.R.D. 115, 121 (N.D. 
9  Cal. 2014) (internal quotations omitted)).) In Lyall v. City of Los Angeles, another District 
10  Judge declined to certify a class defined as individuals โwho did not engage in any conduct 
11  justifying their detention by [Los Angeles Police Department] officers or the officersโ 
12  forced entry over objection to the artistsโ spaceโ because the class was not presently 
13  ascertainable and therefore โunmanageable virtually by definition.โ 2010 WL 11549565, 
14  at *2โ3 (C.D. Cal. May 18, 2010) (internal quotations omitted). 
15    Plaintiffs  and  Defendants  interpret  the  proposed  damages  class  definition 
16  differently. Plaintiffs represent that they intended to define a class not by presupposing that 
17  they win the legal question at issue, but rather by limiting the class to individuals who did 
18  not engage in certain conduct. (Reply at 5โ6; Doc. 165, June 12, 2019, Hearing Transcript 
19  (โHrโg Tr.โ) at 13.) Defendants focus not on the conduct of the class members, but rather 
20  the conclusion that must be drawn from that conductโthat it did not justify Defendantsโ 
21  use of force against them. (Resp. at 13.) 
22    The Court is not entirely convinced that a failsafe class definition must fail in every 
23  instance. But Plaintiffsโ proposed damages class definition can be read to require that a 
24  legal conclusion be reached as to whether individualsโ conduct justified the force used 
25  against them before determining if they are members of the class, which the Court agrees 
26  is inconsistent with the goals of precision, objectivity, and present ascertainability in class 
27  definition. See Hagen v. City of Winnemucca, 108 F.R.D. 61, 63โ64 (D. Nev. 1985).

7  B.  Proposed Injunctive Relief Class 
8    1.  Standing 
9  With regard to Plaintiffsโ proposed injunctive relief class, Defendants argue that 
10  Plaintiffs do not have standing to seek injunctive relief because they have not demonstrated 
11  an actual and imminent repetition of Defendantsโ alleged violations. (Resp. at 24โ27.) A 
12  plaintiff cannot properly represent a class if the plaintiff lacks individual standing. Hawkins 
13  v. Comparet-Cassani, 251 F.3d 1230, 1238 (9th Cir. 2001). Moreover, a plaintiff โmust 
14  demonstrate standing separately for each form of relief sought.โ DaimlerChrysler Corp. v. 
15  Cuno, 547 U.S. 332, 352 (2006). Article III standing has three elements. Lujan v. Defenders 
16  of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560 (1992). First, a plaintiff must have suffered an โinjury in 
17  factโan invasion of a legally protected interest which is (a) concrete and particularized . . . 
18  and (b) actual or imminent, not conjectural or hypothetical.โ Id. (internal citations and 
19  quotations omitted). Second, there must be a causal connection between the injury and the 
20  alleged violation. Id. at 560. Third, it must be likely that the injury will be redressed by a 
21  favorable decision. Id. A plaintiff must allege sufficient, specific facts in the complaint to 
22  establish standing. Schmier v. U.S. Court of Appeals for Ninth Circuit, 279 F.3d 817, 821 
23  (9th Cir. 2002). 
24  An organization has standing โto seek judicial relief from injury to itself and to 
25  vindicate whatever rights and immunities the association itself may enjoy.โ  Warth v. 
26  Seldin, 422 U.S. 490, 511 (1975). An organization also has โassociational standingโ to 
27  bring suit on behalf of its members โwhen its members would otherwise have standing to 
28  sue in their own right, the interests at stake are germane to the organizationโs purpose, and 
 
- 13 - 

 
 
 
 
1  neither the claim asserted nor the relief requested requires the participation of individual 
2  members in the lawsuit.โ Friends of the Earth, Inc. v. Laidlaw Envtl. Servs. (TOC), Inc., 
3  528 U.S. 167, 181 (2000) (citing Hunt v. Wash. State Apple Adver. Commโn, 432 U.S. 333, 
4  343 (1977)). 
5  To be a class representative seeking injunctive relief, a plaintiff โmust demonstrate 
6  โthat he is realistically threatened by a repetition of [the violation].โโ Armstrong v. Davis, 
7  275 F.3d 849, 860โ61 (9th Cir. 2001) (quoting City of Los Angeles v. Lyons, 461 U.S. 95, 
8  109 (1983)), overruled on other grounds by Johnson v. California, 543 U.S. 499 (2005). A 
9  plaintiff โneed not establish that future harm is certain, or even probableโ but โmust 
10  establish that recurrence is not โconjecturalโ or โhypothetical.โโ MIWON, 246 F.R.D. at 628 
11  (citing Lyons, 461 U.S. at 105โ08). 
12  Here, Plaintiffs contend that they suffered actual injuries as a result of deficient PPD 
13  policies and that Defendantsโ conduct at the protest was officially sanctioned behavior 
14  violative of Plaintiffsโ federal rights. (Reply at 15โ16.) Defendants frame their conduct at 
15  the protest by stating, โofficers used types of force they rarely use, in response to sudden 
16  and specific threats, in an unusually tense high-security atmosphere,โ such that Plaintiffs 
17  are not realistically threatened by a repetition of the violations they allege occurred in 
18  response to the protest. (Resp. at 28.) 
19  The Court notes that although the named Plaintiffs allege their First Amendment 
20  rights have been chilled by Defendantsโ conduct, the evidence shows they have attended 
21  demonstrations in Phoenix since PPDโs use of force at issue in this lawsuit. The Court will 
22  accept Plaintiffsโ position that โchillingโ free speech rights is not equivalent to preventing 
23  Plaintiffs from protesting, but rather has made them more reluctant or fearful to do soโa 
24  proposition Defendants do not appear to challenge. (Hrโg Tr. at 29โ31.) 
25  With regard to whether Plaintiffs are realistically threatened by a repetition of 
26  Defendantsโ alleged violations, in Armstrong, the Ninth Circuit stated there are at least two 
27  ways to demonstrate that an injury is likely to recur for the purposes of standing to seek 
28  injunctive relief. 275 F.3d at 861.  
 
- 14 - 

 
 
 
 
1   
First, a plaintiff may show that the defendant had, at the time of the injury, a 
2 
written policy, and that the injury stems from that policy. In other words, 
3  where the harm alleged is directly traceable to a written policy, there is an 
implicit likelihood of its repetition in the immediate future. Second, the 
4 
plaintiff may demonstrate that the harm is part of a pattern of officially 
5  sanctioned . . . behavior, violative of the plaintiffsโ [federal] rights. Thus, 
where the defendants have repeatedly engaged in the injurious acts in the 
6 
past, there is a sufficient possibility that they will engage in them in the near 
7  future to satisfy the realistic repetition requirement. 
8  Id. at 861 (internal quotations and citations omitted). 
9    As for the second of these ways of demonstrating a realistic likelihood of recurrence, 
10  the parties dispute whether PPDโs past conduct is sufficient to indicate that PPD will 
11  engage in a use of force in the future similar to that alleged by Plaintiffs in this case. But 
12  the Court finds that Plaintiffs have provided enough policy evidence to meet the first of the 
13  two tests set forth in Armstrong. Specifically, Plaintiffs point to evidence that PPD had no 
14  policy in place at the time of the protest regarding the use of tear gas/chemical agents, 
15  which is directly related to Plaintiffsโ alleged injuries. (Reply at 15.) Moreover, Plaintiffs 
16  provide evidence that PPD did not change its procedures or implement corrective actions 
17  after the protest, and indeed its Chief ratified PPDโs conduct after the event. (Reply at 15โ
18  16.) Because the harm Plaintiffs allege is traceable to PPDโs policies, or lack thereof, the 
19  Court can infer a realistic repetition of PPDโs course of action sufficient for standing 
20  purposes. 
21      2.  Rule 23(a) Elements 
22    The parties do not raise new arguments regarding whether Plaintiffsโ proposed 
23  injunctive relief class meets the Rule 23(a) requirements of numerosity, commonality, 
24  typicality, and adequacy of representation, as applied to the individual Plaintiffs and the 
25  organizational Plaintiffs in vindicating their own interests and those of their members. 
26  Instead, Defendants point out that a class action is not necessary to obtain injunctive relief 
27  when an individual plaintiff can obtain the same relief (Resp. at 27)โa proposition with 
28  which, as a practical matter, the Court agrees. However, because Plaintiffsโ damages class 
 
- 15 - 

 
 
 
 
1  will be certified and the issues involved in seeking damages and injunctive relief largely 
2  intersect, allowing the injunctive relief class to proceed will not result in substantial 
3  unfairness or inefficiency. The Court will thus certify Plaintiffsโ proposed injunctive class. 
4    C.  Other Motions 
5    Defendants filed a Motion for Leave to Supplement the Class Certification Record 
6  (Doc. 138), which Plaintiffs opposed with a Motion to Strike (Doc. 146). The Court 
7  reviewed the deposition transcripts provided by Defendants (Docs. 139, 140) together with 
8  their Motion and did not find Defendantsโ summaries to be akin to additional briefing. The 
9  Court will therefore grant Defendantsโ Motion for Leave to Supplement (Doc. 138), grant 
10  Defendantsโ associated Motion to Seal (Doc. 141), and deny Plaintiffsโ Motion to Strike 
11  (Doc. 146). 
12  Defendants also filed a Motion for Leave to File a Sur-Reply (Doc. 144), which 
13  Plaintiffs opposed (Doc. 148). Because the Court did not rely on Defendantsโ proposed 
14  Sur-Reply in resolving Plaintiffsโ Amended Motion for Class Certification (Doc. 101), the 
15  Court will deny Defendantsโ Motion for Leave to File a Sur-Reply (Doc. 144) as moot. 
16    IT IS THEREFORE ORDERED granting in part and denying in part Plaintiffsโ 
17  Amended  Motion  for  Class  Certification  (Doc.  101).  The  Court  certifies  Plaintiffsโ 
18  proposed subclass (a) of the damages class with the modification to the class definition 
19  described in this Order, as well as Plaintiffsโ proposed injunctive relief class. The Court 
20  denies certification of Plaintiffsโ proposed damages subclass (b). 
21    IT  IS  FURTHER  ORDERED  granting  Defendantsโ  Motion  for  Leave  to 
22  Supplement the Class Certification Record (Doc. 138) and directing the Clerk of Court to 
23  file on the docket the documents currently lodged at Docs. 139 and 140. 
24  IT IS FURTHER ORDERED granting the Motion to File Exhibit under Seal 
25  (Doc. 141) and directing the Clerk of Court to file under seal the document currently lodged 
26  under seal at Doc. 142. 
27   IT IS FURTHER ORDERED denying as moot Defendantsโ Motion for Leave to 
28  File a Sur-Reply (Doc. 144). 
 
- 16 - 

 
 
 
 
1  IT IS FURTHER ORDERED denying Plaintiffsโ Motion to Strike Portions of 
2  Defendantsโ Supplements or Alternatively for Leave to Respond to Defendantsโ Filings 
3  (Doc. 146). 
4    Dated this 30th day of September, 2019. 
5 
   
Honorable John J. Tuchi 
6 
  United States District Judge

documents.text:
Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 1 of 34
 
 
 
1  WO 
 
2 
 
3   
 
4 
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
5  FOR THE DISTRICT OF ARIZONA 
 
6   
Puente, et al.,  No. CV-18-02778-PHX-JJT 
7     
Plaintiffs,  ORDER  
8     
v.  
9 
 
City of Phoenix, et al., 
10 
 
Defendants. 
 
11 
 
12 
13    At issue are three Motions for Summary Judgment. First, Plaintiffs filed a Motion 
14  for Partial Summary Judgment (redacted Doc. 246, sealed Doc. 257, โPMSJโ) along with 
15  a Statement of Facts (redacted Doc. 247, sealed Doc. 257-1, โPSOFโ), to which Defendants 
16  filed a Response (redacted Doc. 285, sealed Doc. 289, โDefs.โ Resp.โ) and Controverting 
17  Statement of Facts (redacted Doc. 286, sealed Doc. 290, โDCSOFโ), and Plaintiffs filed a 
18  Reply (redacted Doc. 309, sealed Doc. 314, โPls.โ Replyโ). Second, Defendants filed a 
19  Motion for Summary Judgment as to Plaintiffsโ Classwide Claims (redacted Doc. 271, 
20  sealed Doc. 276, โDMSJ #1โ) along with a Statement of Facts (redacted Doc. 273, sealed 
21  Doc. 278, โDSOFโ), to which Plaintiffs filed a Response (redacted Doc. 291, sealed 
22  Doc. 298, โPls.โ Resp. #1โ) and Controverting Statement of Facts (redacted Doc. 293, 
23  sealed Doc. 299, โPCSOFโ), and Defendants filed a Reply (redacted Doc. 304, sealed 
24  Doc. 313, โDefs.โ Reply #1โ). Third, Defendants filed a Motion for Summary Judgment as 
25  to Plaintiffsโ Individual Claims (redacted Doc. 272, sealed Doc. 277, โDMSJ #2โ), to which 
26  Plaintiffs filed a Response (Doc. 292, โPls.โ Resp. #2โ), and Defendants filed a Reply 
27  (Doc. 308,  โDefs.โ  Reply  #2โ).1  The  Court  also  considered  Plaintiffsโ  Notice  of 
 
28  1 The parties each filed an omnibus Statement of Facts (DSOF, PCSOF) in support of their 
arguments with respect to both of Defendantsโ Motions for Summary Judgment. 
 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 2 of 34
 
 
 
1  Supplemental Authority in Support of Opposition to Defendantsโ Motion for Summary 
2  Judgment (Doc. 321) and Defendantsโ Response thereto (Doc. 322). (See Doc. 334.) The 
3  Court elects to resolve the partiesโ cross motions for summary judgment without oral 
4  argument.2 See LRCiv 7.2(f). 
5  I.  BACKGROUND 
6  On  August  22,  2017,  President  Donald  Trump  held  a  rally  at  the  Phoenix 
7  Convention Center, and approximately 6,000 demonstratorsโboth pro-Trump and anti-
8  Trumpโgathered outside the Convention Center. The Phoenix Police Department (โPPDโ) 
9  had about a weekโs advance notice of the rally, during which it made preparations to try to 
10  ensure the safety of the downtown area and the public during the expected demonstrations. 
11  The preparations included setting up a โfree speech zoneโ designated for anti-Trump 
12  demonstrators on the north side of the Convention Center, across Monroe Street. The free 
13  speech zone was bordered by 2nd Street to the west, 3rd Street to the east, and Monroe 
14  Street to the south, and demarcated by a three-foot high pedestrian fence and โDo Not 
15  Crossโ tape. PPD anticipated that certain groups of demonstrators would be present, 
16  including Antifaโa national, militant political protest movement opposing fascism and 
17  right-wing ideology whose groups had disrupted several other demonstrations, including 
18  one in Charlottesville, Virginia, in the weeks preceding President Trumpโs Phoenix visitโ
19  as  well  as  Plaintiff  Puenteโa  Phoenix  grassroots  organization  representing  migrant 
20  communities through lobbying, advocacy, and activismโand Plaintiff Poder in Action 
21  (โPoderโ)โa Phoenix grassroots organization with a mission of empowering victims of 
22  injustice through leadership development, civic engagement, and policy advocacy. 
23    In  a  Presidential  Visit  After-Action  Report  (Doc.  101-3  at  2โ35,  Bates  Nos. 
24  COP014832โ014865, โPPD Reportโ), Defendant PPD Chief Jeri Williams stated that, on 
25  the day of the rally, PPD deployed approximately 985 officers around the Convention 
26  Center. According to the report, large crowds of demonstrators began arriving by 11:00 a.m. 
27 
 
2 Because the Court refrains from explicitly referring to sealed evidence in this Order, the 
28 
Court enters the Order on the public docket. 
 
- 2 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 3 of 34
 
 
 
1  and, although PPD officers observed minor altercations and a few water bottles being 
2  thrown at rally attendees lining up to enter the Convention Center, the demonstrations 
3  proceeded generally without incident during the day. 
4  The  rally  inside  the  Convention  Center  began  at  6:30  p.m.  At  approximately 
5  8:15 p.m., after PPD officers around 2nd Street and Monroe reported that water bottles 
6  were being thrown at them, officers used a Long Range Acoustic Device (โLRADโ) to 
7  make announcements instructing individuals to stop throwing objects. At 8:23 p.m., 15 to 
8  20 individuals PPD had identified as Antifa put up large banners near the fence along 
9  Monroe,  which  concealed  their  activities  from  PPD  officers.  PPD  deployed  Tactical 
10  Response Unit (โTRUโ) personnel, including grenadiers trained in the deployment of 
11  chemical munitions, across from the area where Antifa had gathered. Just after 8:32 p.m., 
12  PPD officers observed Antifa pushing or shaking the fence in what appeared to be a breach. 
13    On orders from Field Force Commander Lt. Benjamin Moore, PPD deployed its 
14  first munition in front of Antifa just before 8:33 p.m. in the form of pepper balls on the 
15  ground, which cleared most individuals from the immediate vicinity. Thereafter, PPD 
16  officers reported that rocks and bottles were being thrown and, at 8:34, officers reported 
17  that canisters of some kind of tear gas were thrown at them. At that point, PPD officers 
18  donned gas masks and, at 8:34 to 8:35, the grenadiers deployed inert smoke bombs. Large 
19  numbers of demonstrators began to clear the area.  
20  After officers noted that smoke canisters were being kicked and thrown back and a 
21  spear-like object and an incendiary device were thrown at them, at 8:35 to 8:36, the 
22  grenadiers were ordered to deploy CS gasโa type of tear gasโin what they perceived to 
23  be focused locations. Plaintiff Jacinta Gonzalez Goodman alleges she inhaled gas. Plaintiff 
24  Ira Yedlin, who was standing near the area where Antifa had been, was hit five times by 
25  projectiles. The grenadiers also deployed aerial flash bangs intended to act as auditory 
26  warnings. Demonstrators began to run away and, by 8:39, the area where individuals had 
27  been throwing projectiles was mostly empty, although demonstrators remained to the east 
28  and west of the area. 
 
- 3 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 4 of 34
 
 
 
1    From 8:36 to 8:45, PPD used additional smoke canisters and pepper balls to clear 
2  an area so that officers could form skirmish lines to disperse the remaining individuals. 
3  Helicopters from the PPD Air Unit began arriving at 8:40, and they started making 
4  announcements directing the crowd to disperse at 8:52. In this time period, the grenadiers 
5  deployed smoke canisters, pepper balls, muzzle blasts, and OC bulletsโbullets filled with 
6  pepper sprayโat remaining individuals, and a munition hit Plaintiff Cynthia Guillen. Lines 
7  of PPD officers with riot shields began marching to move the crowd at 8:56. At some point 
8  between  8:42  and  8:47,  PPD  had  made  the  final  determination  that  the  crowd  was 
9  unlawfully assembled, so at 9:02, an official unlawful assembly announcement was made 
10  via a public address system from a marked police vehicle on the ground. 
11    Thereafter, the grenadiers deployed munitions in the form of pepper balls, OC 
12  bullets, muzzle blasts, and CS gas canisters at anyone who approached a police officer, and 
13  Plaintiff Janet Travis was hit in the back and pepper sprayed. PPD officers told the press 
14  to leave the area at 9:20. The crowd was dispersed and gone from the free speech area by 
15  9:56 p.m.  
16  Over the course of the evening, PPD documented eight Incident Reportsโfor 
17  criminal  damage,  disorderly  conduct,  aggravated  assault  on  Police,  and  unlawful 
18  assemblyโand made five arrests of individuals who are not named Plaintiffs in this action. 
19  After the rally, Chief Williams publicly acknowledged that she directed PPDโs actions 
20  against the protestors and that the actions were appropriate. 
21    On September 4, 2018, Plaintiffs filed suit against the City of Phoenix and certain 
22  PPD  membersโincluding  Chief  Williams,  Lt.  Moore,  Grenadier  Team  Leader  Sgt. 
23  Douglas McBride, and Grenadiers Robert Scott, Christopher Turiano, Glenn Neville, John 
24  Sticca, Lane White, Jeffrey Howell, and George Herrโraising four claims: (1) a claim 
25  under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 for excessive use of force during a search or seizure under the 
26  Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments; (2) a ยง 1983 claim for infringement of Plaintiffsโ 
27  freedom of speech and association rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments; (3) a 
28  ยง 1983 claim for due process violations under the Fourteenth Amendment; and (4) a ยง 1983 
 
- 4 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 5 of 34
 
 
 
1  claim for equal protection violations under the First and Fourteenth Amendments. (Doc. 1, 
2  Compl.)  
3  After Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed certain claimsโincluding the claims in their 
4  entirety against  Defendants  Neville, Sticca,  and Whiteโthe  six  Plaintiffsโ individual 
5  claims remain against Defendants the City, Chief Williams, Lt. Moore, and Sgt. McBride. 
6  (Compl.; Doc. 281.) Additionally, the individual Plaintiffs bring claims as follows: Travis 
7  against Turiano and Howell; Yedlin against Scott, Howell, and Herr; and Guillen against 
8  Scott, Turiano, Howell, and Herr. (Compl.; Doc. 281.) 
9  Plaintiffs moved to certify their claims as a class action under Federal Rule of Civil 
10  Procedure 23, and the Court granted their Motion in part. (Doc. 191.) The Court certified 
11  a โdamages classโ consisting of  
12 
those persons who were present on August 22, 2017, at the Trump Protest 
area north of the Convention Center which was designated as the โfree-
13 
speech zoneโ (the area for anti-Trump protestors bounded to the south by 
14  Monroe Street, 2nd Street to the west, and 3rd street to the east) and forced 
by PPD onto adjacent streets at any point between 8:25 and 10:00 P.M., who 
15 
neither threw objects nor attempted to breach the โfree speech zoneโ barrier 
16  along Monroe Street, and who were subjected to the PPDโs dispersal by the 
use of force, or other unlawful police activity arising from the police response 
17 
to anti-Trump protestors. 
18   
19  (Compl. ยถ 112, as altered in Doc. 191.) The damages class consists of only one certified 
20  subclass: (a) โAll persons who were unlawfully dispersed by the use of gas, pepper spray, 
21  pepper bullets, or other chemical agents.โ (Compl. ยถ 112.) Plaintiffs Travis, Guillen, and 
22  Gonzalez Goodman are class representatives for the damages class.  
23    The Court also certified an โinjunctive relief classโ consisting of 
 
24 
all persons who have in the past, including those present at the anti-Trump 
25  protest on August 22, 2017, between 8:25 and 10:00 P.M., or may in the 
future, participate in, or be present at, demonstrations within the City of 
26 
Phoenix in the exercise of their rights of free speech and assembly without 
27  engaging in any conduct justifying the use of force. 
 
28 
 
- 5 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 6 of 34
 
 
 
1  (Compl. ยถ 113.) Plaintiffs Travis, Guillen, and Gonzalez Goodman as well as the two 
2  Plaintiff organizations, Puente and Poder, are class representatives for the injunctive relief 
3  class. 
4  The Court now resolves the partiesโ cross-motions for summary judgment. 
5  II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
6  Under Rule 56(c) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, summary judgment is 
7  appropriate when: (1) the movant shows that there is no genuine dispute as to any material 
8  fact; and (2) after viewing the evidence most favorably to the non-moving party, the 
9  movant is entitled to prevail as a matter of law. Fed. R. Civ. P. 56; Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 
10  477 U.S. 317, 322โ23 (1986); Eisenberg v. Ins. Co. of N. Am., 815 F.2d 1285, 1288โ89 
11  (9th Cir. 1987). Under this standard, โ[o]nly disputes over facts that might affect the 
12  outcome of the suit under governing [substantive] law will properly preclude the entry of 
13  summary judgment.โ  Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986). A 
14  โgenuine issueโ of material fact arises only โif the evidence is such that a reasonable jury 
15  could return a verdict for the nonmoving party.โ Id. 
16  In considering a motion for summary judgment, the court must regard as true the 
17  non-moving partyโs evidence, if it is supported by affidavits or other evidentiary material. 
18  Celotex, 477 U.S. at 324; Eisenberg, 815 F.2d at 1289. However, the non-moving party 
19  may not merely rest on its pleadings; it must produce some significant probative evidence 
20  tending to contradict the moving partyโs allegations, thereby creating a material question 
21  of fact. Anderson, 477 U.S. at 256โ57 (holding that the plaintiff must present affirmative 
22  evidence in order to defeat a properly supported motion for summary judgment); First Natโl 
23  Bank of Ariz. v. Cities Serv. Co., 391 U.S. 253, 289 (1968). 
24  โA summary judgment motion cannot be defeated by relying solely on conclusory 
25  allegations unsupported by factual data.โ Taylor v. List, 880 F.2d 1040, 1045 (9th Cir. 
26  1989). โSummary judgment must be entered โagainst a party who fails to make a showing 
27  sufficient to establish the existence of an element essential to that partyโs case, and on 
28 
 
- 6 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 7 of 34
 
 
 
1  which that party will bear the burden of proof at trial.โ United States v. Carter, 906 F.2d 
2  1375, 1376 (9th Cir. 1990) (quoting Celotex, 477 U.S. at 322). 
3  III.  ANALYSIS 
4    A.  Class Claims 
5    The Court begins by determining whether a genuine dispute of material fact exists 
6  with regard to Plaintiffsโ class claims. Plaintiffs bring class claims against individual PPD 
7  officers and the City under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, alleging that the use of chemical agents 
8  violated class membersโ First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights.  โA plaintiff may 
9  bring an action under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 to redress violations of his โrights, privileges, or 
10  immunities secured by the Constitution and [federal] lawsโ by a person or entity, including 
11  a municipality, acting under color of state law.โ Awabdy v. City of Adelanto, 368 F.3d 1062, 
12  1066 (9th Cir. 2004) (citing Monell v. Depโt of Social Servs. of the City of N.Y., 436 U.S. 
13  658, 690โ95 (1978)). To succeed in a claim against an officer, the class must prove that 
14  the officerโs conduct โwas the actionable cause of the claimed injury,โ which includes 
15  โboth causation-in-fact and proximate causation.โ Harper v. City of Los Angeles, 533 F.3d 
16  1010, 1026 (9th Cir. 2008). 
17      1.  Excessive Force 
18    First, Plaintiffs, on behalf of the class, claim that PPDโs use of chemical agents 
19  without sufficient warning on protestors who neither threw objects nor attempted to breach 
20  the free speech zone barrier along Monroe Street was an excessive use of force constituting 
21  a violation of the class membersโ Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment substantive due 
22  process rights. (Compl., Counts 1 and 3.) 
23        a.  Class Claims Against Individual Defendants 
24    โQualified immunity shields an official from damages in a civil suit unless the 
25  plaintiff can make the showing that the officialโs actions violated a constitutional right, and 
26  that the right was โclearly establishedโ at the time of the violative conduct.โ Nelson v. City 
27  of Davis, 685 F.3d 867, 875 (9th Cir. 2012) (citing Harlow v. Fitzgerald, 457 U.S. 800, 
28 
 
- 7 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 8 of 34
 
 
 
1  818 (1982)). โTo survive the defendantโs invocation of qualified immunity, the plaintiff 
2  must succeed on both prongs.โ Id. 
3          i.  Constitutional Right at Issue 
4    With regard to whether individual PPD officersโ use of force was unconstitutionally 
5  excessive, the parties dispute whether the Fourth or Fourteenth Amendment applies, the 
6  resolution of which turns on whether the officers seized the class members. โA person is 
7  seized by the police and thus entitled to challenge the governmentโs action under the Fourth 
8  Amendment when the officer, by means of physical force or show of authority, terminates 
9  or restrains his freedom of movement through means intentionally applied.โ Brendlin v. 
10  California, 551 U.S. 249, 254 (2007) (internal quotations and citations omitted). Any such 
11  seizure is unconstitutional only if it is unreasonable.  Nelson, 685 F.3d at 878. โThe 
12  โreasonablenessโ of a particular use of force must be judged from the perspective of a 
13  reasonable officer on the scene, rather than with the 20/20 vision of hindsight.โ Graham v. 
14  Connor, 490 U.S. 386, 396 (1989). The inquiry is thus โwhether the officersโ actions are 
15  โobjectively reasonableโ in light of the facts and circumstances confronting them.โ Id. at 
16  397. To resolve this question, a court must balance โthe nature and quality of the intrusion 
17  on the individualโs Fourth Amendment interests against the countervailing governmental 
18  interests at stake.โ Id. at 396. 
19    In contrast, the Fourteenth Amendment guarantee of substantive due process, which 
20  still applies to police action even if it did not occur โin the course of an arrest, investigatory 
21  stop, or other seizure,โ id. at 395, requires a court to determine whether officersโ conduct 
22  โshocks the conscience,โ County of Sacramento v. Lewis, 523 U.S. 833, 854 (1988).  
23  Where  actual  deliberation  is  practical,  then  an  officerโs  โdeliberate 
indifferenceโ may suffice to shock the conscience. On the other hand, where 
24 
a law enforcement officer makes a snap judgment because of an escalating 
25  situation, his conduct may only be found to shock the conscience if he acts 
with a purpose to harm unrelated to legitimate law enforcement objectives. 
26 
For example, a purpose to harm might be found where an officer uses force 
27  to bully a suspect or โget even.โ 
28  Wilkinson v. Torres, 610 F.3d 546, 554 (9th Cir. 2010) (internal citations omitted).  
 
- 8 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 9 of 34
 
 
 
1    At issue, then, is whether the officers seized class members by deploying inert 
2  smoke and CS gas to keep the crowd from entering Monroe Street and ultimately disperse 
3  the crowd, such that the Fourth Amendment standard applies to the officersโ conduct. 
4  Defendants argue that the officersโ use of chemical munitions was not a seizure because it 
5  did not result in class membersโ belief that they were โnot free to leave,โ but rather that 
6  they were โnot free to stay.โ (DMSJ #1 at 7 (citing Michigan v. Chesternut, 486 U.S. 567, 
7  573 (1988) (holding a seizure occurs if a person believes he or she is โnot free to leaveโ)).) 
8    The cases Plaintiffs cite from the Supreme Court and within the Ninth Circuit in 
9  support  of  their  argument  that  class  members  were  seized  by  Defendants  are 
10  distinguishable from the present one. In Brendlin, the Supreme Court held that seizure does 
11  not require a formal arrest, but rather a person is seized during a traffic stop if the person 
12  does not believe he or she is free to โterminate the encounterโ with the police. 551 U.S. at 
13  257. As Defendants argue, the opposite occurred here, and Plaintiffs present no evidence 
14  that class members did not feel free to terminate the encounter with Defendants. 
15  In Nelson, police officers fired pepper balls at a group of confined partygoers, 
16  striking the plaintiff in the eye and causing him to collapse and lie on the ground for ten to 
17  fifteen minutes. 685 F.3d at 874. The Ninth Circuit made clear that the plaintiff was โhit 
18  by a projectile that [officers] intentionally fired towards a group of which [the plaintiff] 
19  was a member,โ which was โthe application of physical force to [the plaintiffโs] person as 
20  well as the termination of his movement,โ constituting a seizure. Id. at 877. The court relied 
21  on the facts that the officers acted intentionally in firing the shots and that the plaintiff was 
22  hit and thereby immobilized. Id. Contrary to Plaintiffsโ insinuation in their brief (Pls.โ Resp. 
23  #1 at 10), the Nelson court did not state that the plaintiff would have been seized had he 
24  not been hit and immobilized. Rather, the court emphasized the plaintiff was hit, through 
25  intentional conduct of the officers, even if they intended โto impact his body elsewhereโ or 
26  โonly to spray him with [the projectileโs] contents.โ Id. But, in contrast to the present case, 
27  the result of that intentional use of force was a โtermination of freedom of movement.โ Id. 
28  at 876. The Court finds the other cases cited by Plaintiffs no more applicable to the present 
 
- 9 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 10 of 34
 
 
 
1  case. E.g., Villanueva v. California, 986 F.3d 1158, 1166 (9th Cir. 2021) (finding an 
2  officerโs action of shooting at a truck to stop its movement to be a Fourth Amendment 
3  seizure); Hamilton v. City of Olympia, 687 F. Supp. 2d 1231 (W.D. Wash. 2009) (finding 
4  an officerโs application of pepper spray to the plaintiffโs face, temporarily blinding him, 
5  โterminatedโ the plaintiffโs freedom of movement). 
6  In further support of their Fourth Amendment argument, Plaintiffs cite a case from 
7  outside the Ninth Circuit in which the court concluded that the use of tear gas to attempt to 
8  get reporters covering a protest to disperse was a seizure. Quraishi v. St. Charles Cnty., 
9  Mo., 2019 WL 2423321, at *9 (E.D. Mo. June 10, 2019). But on appeal, the Eighth Circuit 
10  recently reversed the District Court on this point because โthe reportersโ freedom to move 
11  was not terminated or restrictedโ by the deployment of tear gas in front of them such that 
12  they did not believe they were free to leave. Quraishi v. St. Charles Cnty., Mo., 986 F.3d 
13  831, 840 (8th Cir. 2021). That court also noted that, to the extent contrary case law from 
14  the Sixth Circuit exists, the Fourth Amendment law in this area was at minimum not clearly 
15  established, which itself entitled the officer to qualified immunity. Id. In an out-of-circuit 
16  case cited by Defendants, eleven plaintiffs encountered tear gas deployed by police officers 
17  that neither restrained nor prevented them from dispersing, and the court found the officersโ 
18  use of tear gas did not constitute a seizure under the Fourth Amendment because the 
19  plaintiffsโ freedom of movement was not terminated. Buck v. City of Albuquerque, 2007 
20  WL 9734037, at *31 (D.N.M. Apr. 11, 2017). The Court finds this case akin to Buck and 
21  finds its reasoning persuasive as applied to the facts of this case and the class membersโ 
22  claims. 
23  Here,  no  evidence  demonstrates  that  a  termination  of  freedom  of  movement 
24  occurred among class members resulting from the officersโ use of chemical agents. The 
25  Court notes that, in certifying the class, it found that the claims of Plaintiffs hit and 
26  potentially  immobilized  by  projectiles  were  too  individualized,  precluding  class 
27  certification on those claims. Thus, to the extent Plaintiffs argue Defendants used force by 
28  way of hitting certain Plaintiffs with projectiles to terminate their freedom of movementโ
 
- 10 -

1  more akin to Nelsonโthe claims predicated on that use of force are individual, not class, 
2  claims, which the Court will examine when it turns to Plaintiffsโ individual claims below. 
3  Accordingly, as urged by Defendants, the Court will apply the standard for a 
4  violation of the Fourteenth Amendment guarantee of substantive due process, and not for 
5  a seizure under the Fourth Amendment, in examining the officersโ use of chemical agents 
6  as applied to the class members.3 See Am. Fedโn of Labor & Cong. of Indus. Orgs. v. City 
7  of Miami, Fla., 637 F.3d 1178, 1190โ91 (11th Cir. 2011) (finding that police officersโ acts 
8  of forcing the plaintiff off Biscayne Boulevard and deploying tear gas to which the plaintiff 
9  was exposed was not a seizure under the Fourth Amendment because โshe still had the 
10  ability to, and indeed did, walk awayโ). 
11        ii.  Evidence of Purpose to Harm 
12  As stated above, under the Fourteenth Amendment, โwhere a law enforcement 
13  officer makes a snap judgment because of an escalating situation, his conduct may only be 
14  found to shock the conscience if he acts with a purpose to harm unrelated to legitimate law 
15  enforcement objectives.โ Wilkinson, 610 F.3d at 554. Although Plaintiffs argue that the 
16  evidence showsโor at least that there is a genuine dispute of material factโthat the PPD 
17  officers had time to deliberate before they acted, subjecting the evaluation of their conduct 
18  to the less rigorous โdeliberate indifferenceโ standard, the Court finds that the evidence 
19  indisputably demonstrates a lack of time to deliberate in an escalating security situation. 
20  To begin with, protestors and rally attendees began arriving at 11:00 a.m. on the 
21  morning of the rally, and thousands of people were present in the area by 6:30 p.m. 
22  Throughout the course of the day and while the rally was taking place inside the Convention 
23  Center, no breaches of the pedestrian fencing and โDo Not Crossโ tape on Monroe Street 
24  occurred and the officers did not take any substantial action to limit the crowdโs activity or 
25  expression. The series of events upon which the class membersโ claims are principally 
 
26 
3 Because the Court finds there is insufficient evidence from which a reasonable jury could 
conclude the class members were seized, the Court need not and does not determine in the 
27 
alternative whether Plaintiffs have raised a genuine dispute as to whether the officersโ use 
of force by way of deployment of chemical agents on class members was unreasonable 
28 
under the Fourth Amendment. 
 
- 11 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 12 of 34
 
 
 
1  predicated took place in less than five minutes beginning at 8:32 p.m., when members of 
2  Antifa appeared to attempt to breach the pedestrian fencing and penetrate the โDo Not Crossโ 
3  line. In response, Lt. Moore ordered the use of pepper balls targeted at a limited area where 
4  Antifa was located. The extensive video coverage of the protest provided as evidence by both 
5  sidesโwhich the Court has viewed in its entirety several timesโshows that protestors across 
6  a wide area of the crowd then began throwing a large variety of objects at the officers and, 
7  in response, Lt. Moore ordered the deployment of inert smoke at 8:34 p.m. When the crowd 
8  continued to shower objects on the officersโincluding a spear-like object, an incendiary 
9  device, rocks, and water bottlesโas well as kick canisters at the officers, Lt. Moore ordered 
10  the deployment of CS gas at 8:35 or 8:36 p.m. 
11  From the evidence, no reasonable jury could conclude that Lt. Moore had time to 
12  deliberate prior to acting in response to the sudden, violent turn of events. And he had to 
13  make his decisions keeping in mind not only the safety of the officers and the public but 
14  also the security of the Presidentโs motorcade. He thus was required to make โsnap 
15  judgmentsโ  because  of  an  โescalating  situation.โ  Wilkinson,  610  F.3d  at  554.  As 
16  Defendants point out, the facts here are quite similar to those in Porter v. Osborn, 546 F.3d 
17  1131, 1139 (9th Cir. 2008), in which officers and a motorist had a โfive-minute altercationโ 
18  that presented โan evolving set of circumstancesโ requiring โfast actionsโ and consideration 
19  of โobligations that tend to tug against each other.โ Id.  
20  Plaintiffs argue that PPD had a week to prepare for the rally, was familiar with 
21  Antifaโs tactics before the rally, and deployed the TRU well before the situation escalated, 
22  all giving PPD time to deliberate. But there is unquestionably a distinct difference between 
23  preparation and contingency planning, on one hand, and split-second reactions to an 
24  escalating security situation, on the other. Simply because PPD tried to prepare in advance 
25  for any situation does not mean it had time to deliberate before making its decisions to 
26  react to a sudden escalation in crowd violence beginning at 8:32 p.m. See id. at 1140 (noting 
27  that โonce [the driverโs] evasive actions began the officers had to react quickly,โ and 
28  โwhether [the defendant officerโs] conduct shocks the conscience must be evaluated under 
 
- 12 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 13 of 34
 
 
 
1  the purpose to harm standard of culpabilityโ). The Court thus finds that Lt. Moore and the 
2  officers did not have time to deliberate before deploying chemical agents. 
3  Accordingly,  under  the  Fourteenth  Amendment,  the  Court  must  determine  if 
4  Plaintiffs have demonstrated a genuine issue of fact as to whether the officers acted โwith 
5  a purpose to harm [class members] unrelated to legitimate law enforcement objectives.โ 
6  Wilkinson, 610 F.3d at 554. Plaintiffs argue that a jury could find that the officersโ actions 
7  were โso grossly and unreasonably excessiveโ that they showed a purpose to harm, and 
8  that other evidence also points to a purpose to harm class members. (Pls.โ Resp. #1 at 18 
9  (citing Nehad v. Browder, 929 F.3d 1125, 1139โ40 (9th Cir. 2019) (use of force that is 
10  โgrossly and unreasonably excessiveโ can be evidence of purpose to harm); Foster v. City 
11  of Indio, 908 F.3d 1204, 1211 (9th Cir. 2018) (finding a purpose to harm unrelated to 
12  legitimate law enforcement objectives when force was used against a clearly harmless 
13  suspect)).)  
14  The Court disagrees that the evidence is sufficient for Plaintiffs to make such a 
15  showing. Beginning  with Plaintiffsโ  โotherโ evidence,  Plaintiffs  first point to  certain 
16  grenadiersโ possession of a challenge coinโa coin โproduced by different law enforcement 
17  agencies to commemorate events and collected by officersโ (PSOF ยถ 109)โthat was 
18  produced after the events of August 22, 2017. This particular challenge coin depicts one of 
19  the protestorsโwho by definition is not a class member hereโwho threw and kicked 
20  objects at police officers and who officers ultimately hit with a munition in the lower 
21  abdomen. The altercation was caught on live news video, which was broadcast by news 
22  outlets and instantly became popular on the internet. Multiple products were made for 
23  purchase as a result, including the challenge coin in question with a depiction of the 
24  protestor and the phrase โGood Night Left Nutโ on the front of the coin and โMaking 
25  America Great Again One Nut at a Timeโ and โPhoenix, AZ, August 22, 2017โ on the 
26  back.  (See  generally  DCSOF  ยถยถ  129โ151.)  No  evidence  in  the  record  suggests  any 
27  Defendant participated in the creation of the coin, although four grenadiers in the PPD 
28  possess it and Sgt. McBride posted an image of it on Facebook. While possessing this coin 
 
- 13 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 14 of 34
 
 
 
1  commemorating the injury of a protestor is unseemly at best, it is not sufficiently probative 
2  of purpose to harm class members at the time of the protest, particularly because the coin 
3  was produced and sold by a third party after the protest. 
4  Plaintiffs also proffer a PowerPoint slide used in PPD TRU training that depicted a 
5  leader of one of the Plaintiff organizations in handcuffs, which Plaintiffs also suggest is 
6  probative of purpose to harm. But no corroborating evidence in the record suggests the 
7  image intentionally depicted the particular person or that the creator or viewers of the image 
8  even knew who the person in the image was. This, too, has little to no probative value in 
9  assessing whether Defendants had purpose to harm class members at the time of the protest. 
10  Cf. Jurkowski v. City of Seattle, 2017 WL 4472859, at *12 (W.D. Wash. Oct. 5, 2017) 
11  (noting the use of an image of young black men beating up a white person in a Powerpoint 
12  training presentation was of an anti-violence character and not sufficient proof of intent to 
13  inhibit speech of the defendants at a later protest). 
14  The Court has reviewed the voluminous evidence proffered by the parties in its 
15  entirety and finds that no reasonable jury could conclude that the force Defendants used in 
16  response to Antifaโs attempt to breach the โDo Not Crossโ line and the subsequent, sudden 
17  escalation in violence by protestors was so grossly and unreasonably excessive that it 
18  shocks the conscience and shows a purpose to harm class members rather than a legitimate 
19  law enforcement purpose. Lt Mooreโs decision at 8:32 p.m. to deploy pepper balls in the 
20  limited area occupied by Antifa members after their attempted breach was unquestionably 
21  related to a legitimate law enforcement objective.4  
22  As violence escalatedโthe protest was indisputably no longer โlargely peaceful,โ 
23  as Plaintiffs contendโthe evidence shows Lt. Moore directed officers to warn civilian 
24  contacts in the crowd to stop unlawful activity, and as objects continued to fly toward 
25  officers, Lt. Moore requested a helicopter, which was delayed for security reasons. At 
26

1  8:34 p.m., he directed the grenadiers to deploy inert smoke to act as an additional warning

5  Finally, the evidence shows that individuals over a wide area in the crowd continued

8  Again, no evidence points to a purpose to harm class members where the legitimate law

10  402, 403 (9th Cir. 2007) (affirming summary judgment dismissing claim that โuse of force

12  WL 4472859, at *7โ8 (granting summary judgment for police officers on claim that police 
13  officersโ use of โblast ball deploymentโ shocked the conscience where the deployment was

16  In sum, because Plaintiffs have not met their burden to show a genuine issue of 
17  material fact as to whether the individual Defendants violated the class membersโ Fourth

20  2017. 
21        b.  Municipal Liability 
22  The class also raises ยง 1983 claims against the City. In Monell, the Supreme Court 
23  held that a municipality is not liable for ยง 1983 claims under a theory of respondeat 
24  superior. 436 U.S. at 694. Instead, a plaintiff must show that the municipality has adopted 
25  an โofficial policyโ or โcustomโ that caused the alleged constitutional violation, โwhether 
26  made by its lawmakers or by those whose edicts or acts may fairly be said to represent 
27  official policy.โ Id. โThe โofficial policyโ requirement was intended to distinguish acts of 
28  the municipality from acts of employees of the municipality, and thereby make clear that 
 
- 15 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 16 of 34
 
 
 
1  municipal liability is limited to actions for which the municipality is actually responsible.โ 
2  Pembaur v. City of Cincinnati, 475 U.S. 469, 479 (1986) (quoting Monell, 436 U.S. at 694). 
3  As  Plaintiffs  cannot  show  the  class  membersโ  Fourth  or  Fourteenth  Amendment 
4  substantive due process rights were violated, the related class claims against the City fail 
5  as well. 
6  Because no reasonable jury could conclude from the evidence that class members 
7  were seized under the Fourth Amendment, or that Defendantsโ use of force shocks the 
8  conscience in violation of class membersโ Fourteenth Amendment substantive due process 
9  rights, Defendants are entitled to summary judgment on the class claims of excessive use 
10  of force (Counts 1 and 3). This conclusion naturally leads to the further conclusion that the 
11  class requests for injunctive relief and punitive damages on the same basis also fail. 
12      2.  Free Speech 
13    Plaintiffs on behalf of the class next claim that PPDโs actions on August 22, 2017, 
14  violated their First Amendment rights of freedom of speech, assembly, and association, 
15  which were clearly established at the time, entitling the class to damages under ยง 1983. 
16  (Compl., Count 2.) The individual Defendants again claim they are entitled to qualified

20  Nelson, 685 F.3d at 875. 
21    With regard to the standard the Court should apply in determining whether the 
22  officers violated class membersโ First Amendment rights, Defendants urge the Court to 
23  apply the following Ninth Circuit Model Civil Jury Instruction, a standard Plaintiffs also

25

1 
from continuing to engage in the protected activity; and 
2 
(3)  Chilling  the  class  membersโ  protected  activity  was  a  substantial  or 
3  motivating factor in the defendantโs conduct. 
4  (DMSJ #1 at 9 (citing Ninth Circuit Civil Jury Instruction No. 9.11).) This is also the 
5  standard  the  Court  applied  in  its  class  certification  Order.  (Doc.  191  at  10  (citing 
6  Mendocino Envtl. Ctr. v. Mendocino Cnty., 192 F.3d 1283, 1300 (9th Cir. 1999)).) 
7    Plaintiffs now dispute the use of this standard as applied to their claims because they 
8  โdo not assert a retaliation claim.โ (Pls.โ Resp. #1 at 19.) Instead, they rely on a Second 
9  Circuit case to urge the Court to focus not on whether evidence exists that chilling class 
10  membersโ First Amendment rights was a substantial or motivating factor causing the 
11  officersโ  conduct, but rather  whether the  officers  had adequate justification for their 
12  conduct, which Plaintiffs contend can only arise from a โclear and present danger of riot, 
13  imminent violence, interference with traffic or other immediate threat to public safety.โ

15    The Court agrees with Defendants (Defs.โ Resp. at 9โ12) that Plaintiffsโ reading of 
16  Jones  is  overly  broad  and  inapplicable  to  the  circumstances  here.  In  Cantwell  v. 
17  Connecticut, upon which the Jones court relied, the Supreme Court resolved the question 
18  of when a government may arrest someone for engaging in speech and effectively ban 
19  speech.  310 U.S. 296, 300โ03 (1940) (holding that the arrest of peaceful  Jehovahโs 
20  witnesses going door-to-door exceeded the First Amendment limitations on the stateโs 
21  power to regulate speech). The very different question presented in this case, as well-
22  formulated by Defendants, is when an officer may disperse a group when some but not all 
23  of the group is violent or poses a threat. (Defs.โ Resp. at 11.) The Court concludes that, in 
24  instances such as this one, a plaintiff must demonstrate the defendantโs intent to chill 
25  speech. See Barney v. City of Eugene, 20 F. Appโx 683, 685 (9th Cir. 2001); Jurkowski, 
26  2017 WL 4472859, at *12โ13.  
27    Under either formulation, Plaintiffs have not demonstrated  a genuine issue of 
28  material fact going to whether the officersโ conduct violated the class membersโ First

1  Amendment rights. As Defendants point out and the Court alluded to above in examining 
2  whether the officers  exhibited  a purpose to harm under the Fourteenth Amendment, 
3  Plaintiffs  have  not  produced  probative  evidence  that  chilling  class  membersโ  First 
4  Amendment rights was a substantial or motivating factor that caused the officers to take 
5  the actions they did. (DMSJ #1 at 9 (citing Nieves v. Bartlett, 139 S. Ct. 1715, 1722 (2019); 
6  Dietrich v. John Ascuagaโs Nugget, 548 F.3d 892, 900โ01 (9th Cir. 2008)).) Indeed, the 
7  evidence shows that the demonstrations took place for many hours over the course of the 
8  day and officers took no substantial action to limit protestorsโ speech or assembly; only 
9  when violence erupted did officers deploy chemical agents. The facts thus do not support 
10  a finding of Defendantsโ intent to chill class membersโ First Amendment rights. 
11    As for Plaintiffsโ โclear and present dangerโ formulation, Plaintiffs first contend that 
12  the officers here are subject to First Amendment liability because, by deploying chemical 
13  agents,  they  prevented  peaceful  protestors  from  continuing  to  express  themselves  in 
14  reaction to the unprotected activities of a few protestors (โat most twenty peopleโ). (PMSJ 
15  at 21; Pls.โ Resp. #1 at 19.) Plaintiffs argue that this case lines up with the Ninth Circuitโs 
16  decision in Collins v. Jordan, 110 F.3d 1363, 1372โ73 (9th Cir. 1996), which addressed 
17  demonstrations that occurred in San Francisco after the Rodney King trial verdicts. But in 
18  stating  that  officials  may  not  โsuppress  legitimate  First  Amendment  conduct  as  a 
19  prophylactic measure,โ the Ninth Circuit was addressing a situation in which officials 
20  prevented  demonstrations  based  on  prior  incidents  of  violence  and  the  actions  of 
21  demonstrators in a protest the day before. Id. That is not what occurred in this case. 
22    Instead, as the Court stated in its Fourteenth Amendment analysis, the evidenceโ
23  including hours of videotapeโshows that Antifa members appeared to attempt to breach 
24  the pedestrian fence and โDo Not Crossโ tape onto Monroe Street at 8:32 p.m., and the 
25  officers took a limited, targeted action against those members in response. Only after 
26  protestors  from  across  the  free  speech  zone  showered  officers  with  projectiles  did 
27  Lt. Moore order deployment of, first, inert smoke as a warning to disperse, followed by CS 
28  gas a few minutes later, when no de-escalation of violence occurred. From the evidence, a 
 
- 18 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 19 of 34
 
 
 
1  reasonable jury could only conclude under Plaintiffsโ formulation that there was โa clear 
2  and present danger of riot, imminent violence, interference with traffic or other immediate 
3  threat to public safety.โ See Jones, 465 F.3d at 57. 
4    Plaintiffs also argue that the First Amendment requires a dispersal order before 
5  police may disperse a crowd with chemical agents, and the officersโ failure to effectively 
6  announce a dispersal order was itself a First Amendment violation. (PMSJ at 23โ25; Pls.โ 
7  Reply at 13.) The Court again agrees with Defendants that the applicable case law does not 
8  support that proposition. (Defs.โ Resp. at 12โ14.) All of the cases and the statute upon 
9  which Plaintiffs rely for the theory that a First Amendment violation occurs when a crowd 
10  is dispersed without a warning or dispersal order are in the context of arrests. See Vodak v. 
11  City of Chicago, 639 F.3d 738, 745 (7th Cir. 2011) (stating that โbefore the police could 
12  start arresting peaceable demonstrators for defying their orders they had to communicate 
13  the orders to the demonstratorsโ (emphasis added)); Garcia v. Does, 779 F.3d 84, 94 n.11 
14  (2d Cir. 2015) (stating that Jones, upon which Plaintiffs rely here, held that officers could 
15  not indiscriminately arrest peaceful protestors without an order to disperse). No case 
16  provides that a failure to issue a dispersal order in the absence of arrests constitutes a per 
17  se First Amendment violation, and the Court will not so declare here. 
18  In sum, Plaintiffs have failed to demonstrate a genuine issue of material fact as to 
19  whether chilling class membersโ First Amendment rights was a substantial or motivating 
20  factor that caused the officers to take the actions they did, and the Court also finds (in 
21  Plaintiffsโ  alternative  formulation)  that  no  reasonable  jury  could  conclude  from  the 
22  evidence that the officers did not have adequate justification for their actions. As a result, 
23  the individual Defendants are entitled to qualified immunity for their actions with respect 
24  to class members on August 22, 2017. Because Plaintiffs cannot show the class membersโ 
25  First Amendment rights were violated, the related class claims against the City fail as well. 
26  Defendants are thus entitled to summary judgment on the class-wide ยง 1983 claim of 
27  violation of the rights of speech and association under the First Amendment (Count 2). In 
28  addition, although Plaintiffs did not explicitly request class certification on their claim of

1  an Equal Protection violation under the Fourteenth Amendment (Count 4), that claim fails 
2  with Plaintiffsโ First Amendment claim. See OSU Student Alliance v. Ray, 699 F.3d 1053, 
3  1067 (9th Cir. 2012). For all these reasons, the Court will grant Defendantsโ Motion for 
4  Summary  Judgment  as  to  Plaintiffsโ  Classwide  Claims  (redacted  Doc.  271,  sealed
