6  B.  Individual Claims 
7    The Court now turns to the claims brought by the six Plaintiffs on an individual 
8  basis. To begin with, the Court finds that Defendants are entitled to summary judgment on 
9  the claims of Gonzalez Goodman and the two organizations, Puente and Poder, because 
10  the evidence related to their claims does not go materially further than that pertaining to 
11  the class members, as limited by the class definitions, and the Court already found that 
12  evidence to be insufficient, above. With regard to Plaintiffsโ argument that Puente and 
13  Poder have associational standing to bring claims on behalf of their members (Pls.โ Resp. 
14  #2 at 12), Plaintiffs do not satisfy the third prong of the test announced in  Hunt v. 
15  Washington State Apple Advertising Commission, 432 U.S. 333, 343 (1977). Although 
16  participation of individual members in this lawsuit may not be required by the injunctive 
17  relief requested, it is required in terms of the substance of the remaining claims that would 
18  be  asserted  by  Puente  and  Poder.  The  Court  thus  examines  whether  the  remaining 
19  PlaintiffsโYedlin, Travis, and Guillenโhave raised at least a genuine issue of material 
20  fact as to their claims. 
21      1.  Excessive Force 
22    Unlike the claims of the class members, discussed above, the evidence shows that 
23  the three remaining Plaintiffs all were seized within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment. 
24  After Yedlin inhaled PAVA powder from the grenadiersโ initial deployment of pepper balls 
25  in the area where Antifa members were standing, he shook the fence and the grenadiers 
26  aimed pepper balls at him, hitting him five timesโin the face, lower back, and three times 
27  on the legs. Travis stopped in front of a skirmish line of officers to take a photograph, and 
28  when she turned, a grenadier hit her with a muzzle blast and multiple officers barraged her 
 
- 20 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 21 of 34
 
 
 
1  with pepper spray. As other protestors helped her away, a grenadier hit her with another 
2  muzzle blast. Guillen made a video as protestors fled after grenadiers had deployed 
3  chemical agents, and then remained in the area with other protestors until 8:50 p.m., when 
4  she was hit by a muzzle blast. While Defendants contend all three Plaintiffs could still walk 
5  after they were hit by munitions, their freedom of movement was affected by the officersโ 
6  intentional  actions,  which  the  Court  finds  constituted  a  seizure  under  the  Fourth 
7  Amendment. Brendlin, 551 U.S. at 254 (โA person is seized by the police and thus entitled 
8  to challenge the governmentโs action under the Fourth Amendment when the officer, by 
9  means of physical force or show of authority, terminates or restrains his freedom of 
10  movement through means intentionally applied.โ); see also Nelson, 685 F.3d at 877. 
11    As the Court set forth above, the inquiry into whether the officersโ use of force 
12  during a Fourth Amendment seizure was excessive is subject to a reasonableness test. โThe 
13  โreasonablenessโ of a particular use of force must be judged from the perspective of a 
14  reasonable officer on the scene, rather than with the 20/20 vision of hindsight.โ Graham, 
15  490  U.S.  at  396.  The  inquiry  is  thus  โwhether  the  officersโ  actions  are  โobjectively 
16  reasonableโ in light of the facts and circumstances confronting them.โ Id. at 397. To resolve 
17  this  question,  a  court  must  balance  โthe  nature  and  quality  of  the  intrusion  on  the 
18  individualโs Fourth Amendment interests against the countervailing governmental interests 
19  at stake.โ Id. at 396. 
20    Genuine issues of material fact preclude summary judgment on these Plaintiffsโ 
21  Fourth Amendment claims (Compl., Count 1). On one hand, the government had a stake 
22  in ensuring, among other things, the safety of the public and the officers as well as the 
23  security of transportation routes in the downtown area. On the other hand, the officers used 
24  intermediate force in striking these Plaintiffs with pepper balls and muzzle blasts without 
25  apparent provocation beyond a failure to immediately disperse (and, in the case of Yedlin, 
26  shaking the pedestrian fencing). A jury must decide whether the officers used reasonable 
27  force in the circumstances, or whether they could have employed less forceful or intrusive 
28  means to accomplish the government goals in light of the circumstances they faced. See 
 
- 21 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 22 of 34
 
 
 
1  Nelson, 685 F.3d at 883; Young v. County of Los Angeles, 655 F.3d 1156, 1161 (9th Cir. 
2  2011). 
3      2.  Free Speech 
4    It is a closer question whether a genuine dispute of material fact exists with regard 
5  to the First Amendment claims of Yedlin, Travis, and Guillen. As the Court stated above, 
6  the standard used in the Ninth Circuit to evaluate whether officersโ conduct violated a 
7  plaintiffโs First Amendment rights in instances such as the one presented in this case 
8  includes a showing that chilling those rights was a substantial or motivating factor that 
9  caused the officers to take the actions they did. See Nieves, 139 S. Ct. at 1722; Dietrich, 
10  548 F.3d at 900โ01. To that end, Plaintiffsโ argument, in its entirety, is that โ[t]he additional 
11  facts as to the named Plaintiffs outlined above also raise factual issues about Defendantsโ 
12  desire to chill Plaintiffsโ speech.โ (Pls.โ Resp. #2 at 14.) In support, Plaintiffs cite facts 
13  going to the number of times officers hit Yedlin with pepper balls even though he did not 
14  appear to be part of Antifa; the number of protestors struck by pepper balls over the course 
15  of the evening; and evidence that a grenadier celebrated hitting Travis, that other officers 
16  then used pepper spray on her, and that they struck her again as she was helped away. 
17  (PCSOF ยถยถ 11, 14, 17, 21, 35โ37.)  
18    All of these facts go to whether the officersโ conduct was reasonable under the 
19  Fourth Amendment, but they do not by themselves show that chilling Plaintiffsโ First 
20  Amendment rights was a substantial motivating factor for the officersโ actions, let alone 
21  that the officersโ intent to chill was a but-for cause of their actions. Otherwise, Plaintiffs 
22  have proffered evidence of the challenge coin and training slide, neither of which is 
23  sufficiently probative to the question, as discussed above. For these reasons, and because 
24  Plaintiffsโ  First  Amendment  claims  as  characterized  are  duplicative  of  their  Fourth 
25  Amendment claims, which will go to trial, the Court will grant summary judgment to 
26  Defendants on these Plaintiffsโ First Amendment claims (Compl., Count 2). See Vodak, 
27  639  F.3d  at  750โ51  (characterizing  protestorsโ  First  Amendment  claims  as  โlargely 
28  duplicativeโ of the Fourth Amendment claims and advising they โconfine their claims to 
 
- 22 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 23 of 34
 
 
 
1  the Fourth Amendmentโ). Relatedly, the Court grants summary judgment to Defendants 
2  on these Plaintiffsโ Equal Protection claims (Compl., Count 4). See OSU Student Alliance, 
3  699 F.3d at 1067. 
4      3.  Qualified Immunity 
5    As laid out above, qualified immunity shields an official from damages in a ยง 1983 
6  action if the plaintiff shows that the officialโs conduct violated a constitutional right and 
7  that the right was โclearly establishedโ at the time of the conduct. Nelson, 685 F.3d at 875. 
8  To be clearly established, โ[t]he contours of the right must be sufficiently clear that a 
9  reasonable official would understand that what [the official] is doing violates that right.โ 
10  Anderson v. Creighton, 483 U.S. 635, 640 (1987). Although a case need not be โdirectly 
11  on point, . . . existing precedent must have placed the statutory or constitutional question 
12  beyond debate.โ Ashcroft v. Al-Kidd, 563 U.S. 731, 741 (2011). When factual disputes 
13  exist, summary judgment is appropriate only if the defendant is entitled to qualified 
14  immunity under the facts most favorable to the plaintiff. Blankenhorn v. City of Orange, 
15  485 F.3d 463, 477โ78 (9th Cir. 2007). 
16     Because significant issues remain to be resolved at trial as to the reasonableness of 
17  the officersโ use of force on Yedlin, Travis, and Guillen, the Court looks at Plaintiffsโ 
18  claims regarding the officersโ conduct in the light most favorable to these Plaintiffs to 
19  determine if the right allegedly violated was clearly established at the time. The Court finds 
20  that Plaintiffsโ Fourth Amendment right not to be subjected to unreasonable force during a 
21  seizureโby way of the deployment pepper balls, muzzle blasts, and pepper sprayโwhere 
22  less severe or intrusive means of applying force were available and sufficient in the 
23  circumstances was a clearly established right at the time of the officersโ use of force. See, 
24  e.g., Nelson, 685 F.3d at 875. Defendants are thus not entitled to summary judgment on the 
25  issue of qualified immunity for these Plaintiffsโ Fourth Amendment claims. 
26      4.  Individual Officer Causation 
27    Defendants  argue  that  the  individual  Plaintiffsโ  claims  fail  against  individual 
28  Defendant officers because these Plaintiffs cannot identify which officer caused which 
 
- 23 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 24 of 34
 
 
 
1  injury, and to hold an officer liable, a plaintiff must show the officerโs conduct โwas the 
2  actionable cause of the claimed injury,โ including โboth causation-in-fact and proximate 
3  cause.โ Harper, 533 F.3d at 1026. โThe inquiry into causation must be individualized and 
4  focus  on  the  duties  and  responsibilities  of  each  individual  defendant  whose  acts  or 
5  omissions are alleged to have caused a constitutional violation.โ Leer v. Murphy, 844 F.2d 
6  628, 633 (9th Cir. 1988). 
7    Plaintiffsโ theory of individual officer liability rests on the principle of โintegral 
8  participation,โ which โdoes not require that each officerโs actions themselves rise to the 
9  level of a constitutional violationโ so long as the officer was aware of the decisions to use 
10  force and a participant in the concerted action to use it. Boyd v. Benton Cnty., 374 F.3d 
11  773, 780 (9th Cir. 2004). That is, an officer can be liable for a constitutional violation 
12  โwhere there is a showing of integral participation or personal involvement in the unlawful 
13  conduct, as opposed to mere presence on the scene.โ Bonivert v. City of Clarkston, 883 
14  F.3d  865,  879  (9th  Cir.  2018)  (internal  quotations  and  citation  omitted);  see  also 
15  Blankenhorn, 485 F.3d at 481 & n.12. For example, in Boyd, the Ninth Circuit โrecognized 
16  that officers who provide armed backup, stand at the door with a gun while other officers 
17  conduct a search inside an apartment, and participate in the search operation are integral 
18  participants.โ Id. (citing Boyd, 374 F.3d at 780). 
19    Plaintiffs have pointed to evidence that clearly shows that the individual grenadiers 
20  named as Defendants were not bystanders, but participated in a coordinated TRU effort to 
21  disperse the crowd. From the evidence demonstrating the chaotic nature of the dispersal 
22  action, there is at least a genuine issue of material fact as to whether the individual 
23  grenadiers named as Defendants in the remaining three Plaintiffsโ Fourth Amendment 
24  claims either applied the force giving rise to Plaintiffsโ claimsโdeployment of pepper 
25  balls, muzzle blasts, and pepper sprayโor were aware of the decision to use that force and 
26  participated in a concerted action to use it. Specifically, Plaintiffs point to evidence that 
27  grenadiers Scott, Howell, and Herr participated in the deployment of pepper balls that hit 
28 
 
- 24 -

1  Yedlin.5 (Pls.โ Resp. #2 at 15.) Likewise, they point to evidence that Turiano and Howell 
2  participated in the use of force against Travis, and Scott, Turiano, Howell, and Herr 
3  participated in the use of force against Guillen. (Pls.โ Resp. #2 at 15โ16.) There remain 
4  genuine issues as to whether  the grenadiers either deployed  the particular munitions 
5  themselves that hit Plaintiffs or were simply aware of the decisions to use a particular 
6  munition or combination of munitions against Plaintiffs; indeed, the parties dispute what 
7  munitions actually hit Plaintiffs, let alone who deployed them. (E.g., Pls.โ Resp. #2 at 16 
8  n.3; Defs.โ Reply #2 at 9 n.6.) The Court thus will let stand these Plaintiffsโ Fourth 
9  Amendment claims against the named Defendant grenadiers, and the issues surrounding 
10  causation and integral participation will be resolved at trial. 
11      5.  Supervisor Liability 
12    Next,  Defendants  contend  that  Plaintiffsโ  evidence  is  insufficient  to  hold

15  actions, โeach Government official, his or her title notwithstanding, is only liable for his or 
16  her own conduct.โ Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 677 (2009). Thus, a supervisor may 
17  only be liable 
 
18 
if  either  (1)  he  or  she  was  personally  involved  in  the  constitutional 
19  deprivation,  or  (2)  a  sufficient  causal  connection  exists  between  the

20

scene  of  a  constitutional  violation  or  for  being  a  member  of  the  same 
24 
operational unit as a wrongdoer. 
25 
Felarca v. Birgeneau, 891 F.3d 809, 819โ20 (9th Cir. 2018) (internal quotations and 
26 
citations omitted).

17        b.  Lt. Moore 
18    Likewise, sufficient evidence exists from which a jury could find Lt. Moore liable

24  See id. 
25        c.   Chief Williams 
26    The same cannot be said for Chief Williams. Although the grenadiers, Lt. Moore, 
27  and Sgt. McBride were all in her chain of command, the evidence is not sufficient to 
28  demonstrate that she reasonably should have known that the actions she set in motionโby

3  proffer  insufficient  evidence  to  support  a  conclusion  that  Chief  Williams  failed  to

6  630,  646  (9th  Cir.  1991),  or  that  she  failed  to  adequately  train  the  grenadiers  with 
7  knowledge  that  without  training,  they  would  likely  violate  constitutional  rights,  see 
8  Clement v. Gomez, 298 F.3d 898, 905 (9th Cir. 2002). Finally, Plaintiffsโ contentions that 
9  Chief Williams was โin the vicinityโ and followed radio transmissions throughout the day 
10  but โdid not intervene in the decisions to deploy forceโ are too tenuous to be sufficient. See 
11  Felarca, 891 F.3d at 820โ21. Plaintiffs must show that Chief Williams knew or should 
12  have known that her general orders and delegation of decision-making would cause the 
13  grenadiers to use unconstitutionally excessive force against Plaintiffs in the particular 
14  circumstances the grenadiers were presented with on the ground, which Plaintiffsโ evidence 
15  does not demonstrate. Chief Williams is thus entitled to summary judgment on the claims 
16  against her. 
17      6.  Municipal Liability 
18  The parties cross-move for summary judgment on Plaintiffsโ ยง 1983 claims against 
19  the  City.  As  the  Court  stated  above,  under  Monell,  a  plaintiff  must  show  that  the 
20  municipality  has  adopted  an  โofficial  policyโ  or  โcustomโ  that  caused  the  alleged 
21  constitutional violation, โwhether made by its lawmakers or by those whose edicts or acts 
22  may fairly be said to represent official policy.โ Id. โThe โofficial policyโ requirement was 
23  intended to distinguish acts of the municipality from acts of employees of the municipality, 
24  and  thereby  make  clear  that  municipal  liability  is  limited  to  actions  for  which  the 
25  municipality is actually responsible.โ Pembaur, 475 U.S. at 479 (1986) (quoting Monell, 
26  436 U.S. at 694). 
27  Official policy includes โdecisions of a governmentโs lawmakers,โ โacts of its 
28  policymaking officials,โ โpractices so persistent and widespread as to practically have the 
 
- 27 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 28 of 34
 
 
 
1  force of law,โ or a โdecision not to train certain employees about their legal duty to avoid 
2  violating citizensโ rightsโ where that decision amounted to โdeliberate indifferenceโ to 
3  citizensโ rights. Connick v. Thompson, 563 U.S. 51, 61 (2011) (citations omitted). An 
4  official policy must be the โmoving forceโ behind the constitutional injuries alleged by a 
5  plaintiff for a municipality to be liable. Bd. of Commโrs of Bryan Cnty., Okl. v. Brown, 520 
6  U.S. 397, 404 (1997). โWhere a plaintiff claims that the municipality has not directly 
7  inflicted an injury, but nonetheless has caused an employee to do so, rigorous standards of 
8  culpability and causation must be applied to ensure that the municipality is not held liable 
9  solely for the actions of its employee.โ Id. at 405. 
10  Plaintiffs assert five theories of the Cityโs liability, which the Court now examines 
11  in turn. 
12      a.  Delegation of Policymaking Authority 
13  First, relying on Ulrich v. City and County of San Francisco, 308 F.3d 968, 986 (9th 
14  Cir. 2002), Plaintiffs contend that Chief Williams delegated final policymaking authority 
15  to Lt. Moore, so his decisions constituted City policy, making the City liable for them. 
16  (Pls.โ Resp. #1 at 28.) The Court agrees with Defendants (Defs.โ Resp. at 26โ27) that this 
17  claim has no merit. Under the City Code, Phoenix City Charter, Ch. III ยงยง 1, 2, Chief 
18  Williams is not the final policymaker; the City Council and City Manager are. See Christie 
19  v. Iopa, 176 F.3d 1231, 1235 (9th Cir. 1999) (โWhether an official has final policymaking 
20  authority is a question for the court to decide based on state law.โ) This alone defeats 
21  Plaintiffโs claim. See Ellins v. City of Sierra Madre, 710 F.3d 1049, 1066 (9th Cir. 2013). 
22  Moreover, even if Chief Williams had final policymaking authority to delegate, there is a 
23  distinct  difference  between  delegating  final  policymaking  authority  and  delegating 
24  โdiscretion to act,โ as she did. Christie, 176 F.3d at 1236. Otherwise, โthe result would be 
25  indistinguishable from respondeat superior liability.โ Id. (quoting City of St. Louis v. 
26  Praprotnik, 485 U.S. 112, 126 (1988)). And even if Chief Williams delegated decision-
27  making to Lt. Moore, he was constrained by policies, discussed further below, and subject 
28  to  review  by  others.  Id.  For  these  reasons,  Chief  Williams  did  not  delegate  final 
 
- 28 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 29 of 34
 
 
 
1  policymaking authority to Lt. Moore or any other officer and the City is not liable on this 
2  basis. 
3      b.  Ratification 
4  Next, relying on Gillette v. Delmore, 979 F.2d 1342, 1346โ47 (9th Cir. 1992), 
5  Plaintiffs  argue  that  Chief  Williams  as  final  policymaker  ratified  subordinatesโ 
6  unconstitutional actions by โapplauding the officersโ conduct on numerous occasions,โ 
7  failing โto discipline officers for any of their relevant conduct,โ and failing โto implement 
8  her own departmentโs recommendations to update its policies on crowd control weapons.โ 
9  (Pls.โ Resp. #1 at 28โ29.) To begin with, Chief Williams is not the final policymaker, as 
10  the Court stated above, so this claim fails as well. Moreover, the actions Plaintiffs refer to 
11  occurred after the event, and thus could not have been the โmoving forceโ behind the 
12  grenadiersโ alleged unconstitutional acts. Bd. of Commโrs of Bryan Cnty., Okl., 520 U.S. 
13  at 404. To the extent Plaintiffs argue (Pls.โ Reply at 17โ18) that Chief Williams is liable 
14  for her own conductโwhich goes to supervisor liability, not municipal liabilityโthe Court 
15  already found Plaintiffsโ evidence insufficient for such a conclusion, above. Plaintiffsโ 
16  ratification theory thus fails. 
17      c.  Policies Related to Chemical Agent Deployment 
18  Plaintiffs next contend that the City had โno tear gas policyโ and insufficient protocols 
19  regarding the deployment of munitions, raising municipal liability against it. (Pls.โ Resp. #1

21  multiple reasons. First, in terms of the class claims, the Court found that the deployment of 
22  tear gas to control the sudden eruption of violence did not shock the conscience, and 
23  otherwise the deployment of tear gas does not appear to be at issue in the remaining

25  how and when to deploy chemical agents, of which tear gas is a part, and grenadiers are

27  Indeed, one portion of the policies states that chemical agents may be used only when 
28  โabsolutely necessaryโ and โother passive means have failed to restore order.โ (DSOF 
 
- 29 -

1  ยถ 14(d).) And third, because PPD does have policies applicable to the circumstances here, 
2  Plaintiffs have no evidence that the policies were the but-for or proximate cause of their

4  Plaintiffs argue, as their expert opined, that PPD should have addressed a post-
5  protest recommendation that the TRU establish a protocol for munitions deployment based 
6  on the events of the protest. Post-incident evidence can be probative in evaluating a 
7  municipalityโs policy. Henry v. Cnty. of Shasta, 132 F.3d 512, 519 (9th Cir. 1997), as 
8  amended, 137 F.3d 1372 (9th Cir. 1998), (citing Grandstaff v. City of Borger, 767 F.2d 161 
9  (5th Cir. 1985)). But because the City had a policy in place regarding the deployment of 
10  munitions, the particular post-protest evidence hereโthat the City chose not to add a new 
11  protocolโis  not  sufficiently  probative  to  show  that  the  existing  PPD  policy  was 
12  insufficient, much less that the policy was the but-for or proximate cause of Plaintiffsโ 
13  injuries. For these reasons, Plaintiffsโ defective policy claim fails. 
14      d.  Practice or Custom

25  unconstitutional use of force by PPD had been made in conjunction with the May 2020

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 31 of 34
 
 
 
1  actions in May 2020 and those in 2017 underlying the present matter to be too tenuous for 
2  a reasonable jury to conclude that the City had a practice or custom of using, or turning a 
3  blind eye to the use of, excessive force. 
4      e.  Failure to Train 
5  Lastly, Plaintiffs argue that PPD provided no specific training to officers tailored to 
6  the event, even though it had advance notice of the event, and that the officersโ lack of 
7  training demonstrated a deliberate indifference sufficient to raise municipal liability. (Pls.โ 
8  Resp. #1 at 30โ31 (citing Long v. Cnty. of Los Angeles, 442 F.3d 1178, 1189 (9th Cir. 
9  2006)).) Plaintiffsโ expert opined that PPD officers lacked sufficient training, butโto the 
10  extent  that  testimony  adequately  relied  on  the  record  and  did  not  constitute  legal 
11  conclusions (see Doc. 326)โPlaintiffs do not provide sufficient evidence from which a 
12  reasonable jury could find that โthe need for more or different training [was] so obvious, 
13  and the inadequacy so likely to result in the violation of constitutional rights, that the 
14  policymakers of the city can reasonably be said to have been deliberately indifferent to the 
15  need.โ City of Canton, 489 U.S. at 390. For example, as Defendants point out, Plaintiffs 
16  identify no instance before August 22, 2017, of illegal conduct such as that alleged here 
17  that would have been probative to a finding that officer training was so obviously deficient. 
18  For their part, Defendants point to the extensive training grenadiers completed. (Defs.โ 
19  Reply #1 at 19.) Plaintiffs have not raised a genuine issue of material fact sufficient to 
20  survive summary judgment on their failure to train theory. And because none of Plaintiffsโ 
21  municipal liability theories survives, the City is entitled to summary judgment on the 
22  claims against it. 
23      7.  Injunctive Relief 
24  Next,  the  parties  filed  cross-motions  for  summary  judgment  on  the  issue  of 
25  injunctive relief. In order to obtain a preliminary injunction, each Plaintiff must show that 
26  โ(1) [he/she] is likely to succeed on the merits, (2) [he/she] is likely to suffer irreparable 
27 
 
excessive force was used in the separate incident, and of course this Court would not 
28 
conduct a mini-trial on a separate matter. 
 
- 31 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 32 of 34
 
 
 
1  harm in the absence of preliminary relief, (3) the balance of equities tips in [his/her] favor, 
2  and (4) an injunction is in the public interest.โ Garcia v. Google, Inc., 786 F.3d 733, 740 
3  (9th Cir. 2015) (citing Winter v. Nat. Res. Def. Council, Inc., 555 U.S. 7, 9 (2008)). 
4  In  the  Complaint,  Plaintiffs  seek  โ[a]  preliminary  and  permanent  injunction 
5  prohibiting Defendants from engaging in any of the unconstitutional behaviors as described 
6  herein and to put into place safeguards sufficient to ensure that they do not continue in the 
7  future.โ (Compl. at 46 ยถ B.) In this Order, the Court concludes that Defendants are entitled 
8  to summary judgment on the class claims as well as the claims against the City and Chief 
9  Williams, but that certain individual Plaintiffsโ Fourth Amendment claims against certain 
10  individual officers will proceed to trial. 
11  To the extent these individual Plaintiffs can seek injunctive relief against individual 
12  officers, Plaintiffsโ request for such relief fails the second prong of the Winter test. An 
13  injunction is โunavailable absent a showing of irreparable injury, a requirement that cannot 
14  be met where there is no showing of any real or immediate threat that the plaintiff will be 
15  wronged againโa likelihood of substantial and immediate irreparable injury.โ City of Los 
16  Angeles v. Lyons, 461 U.S. 95, 111 (1983) (internal quotation and citation omitted). In 
17  Lyons, although a police officer used excessive force by way of a chokehold on the plaintiff 
18  during  a  traffic  stop,  the  Supreme  Court  concluded  the  plaintiff  was  not  entitled  to 
19  injunctive  relief  because  of  an  insufficient  โlikelihood  of  substantial  and  immediate 
20  irreparable injuryโ to the plaintiff. The Court concluded โeven assumingโ Lyons would be 
21  stopped again in the โreasonably near future,โ it is โuntenable to assertโ that officers apply 
22  chokeholds at every traffic stop. Id. at 108. 
23  The Court agrees with Defendants that this case is similar to Hernandez v. City of 
24  San Jose, 2019 WL 4450930 (N.D. Cal. Sept. 17, 2019), in which the court examined 
25  whether the plaintiffs injured at an anti-Trump protest by the police officersโ crowd control 
26  tactics could seek injunctive relief. There, Judge Koh stated that the plaintiffsโ claim of 
27  substantial and irreparable injury rested on a โstring of contingencies,โ the entire set of 
28 
 
- 32 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 33 of 34
 
 
 
1  which must be met, including whether the plaintiffs would attend another rally, a protest 
2  would break out, and police would react the same way. Id. at 21โ23.  
3  Here, because Plaintiffs have no remaining claims against the City, injunctive relief 
4  can only be obtained against the individual officers they are suing. That additional fact 
5  makes meeting the string of contingencies even more unlikely; even if Plaintiffs attended 
6  another protest, it is uncertain whether those officers would be present, whether Plaintiffs 
7  would encounter them, whether similar circumstances would arise, and whether those 
8  officers would act in the same way.7 Plaintiffsโ testimony that they intend to attend or have 
9  attended other protests, by itself, is not sufficient under Winter to show a likelihood of 
10  substantial and immediate irreparable injury entitling them to injunctive relief against 
11  individual officers. 
12      8.  Punitive Damages 
13    Finally, Defendants state that the evidence is insufficient for a reasonable jury to 
14  award Plaintiffs punitive damages. โ[A] jury may be permitted to assess punitive damages 
15  in an action under ยง 1983 when the defendantโs conduct is shown to be motivated by evil 
16  motive or intent, or when it involves reckless or callous indifference to the federally 
17  protected rights of others.โ Smith v. Wade, 461 U.S. 30, 56 (1983). 
18    Beyond their brief argument against punitive damages in the context of the class 
19  membersโ claims (DMSJ #1 at 35; Defs.โ Reply #1 at 21), Defendants do not provide legal 
20  support for their contention that the individual Plaintiffs should be precluded from seeking 
21  punitive damages. There is some overlap between a finding of purpose to harm with regard 
22  to a Fourteenth Amendment claimโwhich the Court determined Plaintiffs could not prove 
23  with regard to the class claimsโand the finding required for punitive damages of either evil 
24  motive or intent, or reckless or callous indifference to Plaintiffsโ rights. But the individual 
25  Plaintiffsโ punitive damages claim pertains to individual officersโ actions beyond the conduct 
26  pertaining just to the class membersโ claims. The Court finds that the evidence is sufficient 
 
27 
7 To the extent the Complaint alleges that Plaintiffs were targeted specifically because they 
were anti-Trump protestors (e.g., Compl. ยถยถ 7, 9โ11), the string of contingencies would be 
28 
even more difficult to meet in the near future.  
 
- 33 - 

  Case 2:18-cv-02778-JJT   Document 336   Filed 02/07/22   Page 34 of 34
 
 
 
1  for a jury to find the individual Defendantsโ use of force involved a reckless or callous 
2  indifference to the rights of Yedlin, Travis, and Guillen. Accordingly, the Court denies 
3  Defendantsโ motion as it pertains to punitive damages on Plaintiffsโ remaining claims. See 
4  Wallisa v. City of Hesparia, 369 F. Supp. 3d 990, 1021 (C.D. Cal. 2019). 
5    IT IS THEREFORE ORDERED denying Plaintiffsโ Motion for Partial Summary 
6  Judgment (redacted Doc. 246, sealed Doc. 257). 
7    IT  IS  FURTHER  ORDERED  granting  Defendantsโ  Motion  for  Summary 
8  Judgment as to Plaintiffsโ Classwide Claims (redacted Doc. 271, sealed Doc. 276). 
9    IT IS FURTHER ORDERED granting in part and denying in part Defendantsโ 
10  Motion for Summary Judgment as to Plaintiffsโ Individual Claims (redacted Doc. 272, 
11  sealed Doc. 277). The Court will proceed to trial on the Fourth Amendment Excessive 
12  Force claims (Count 1) of individual Plaintiffs as follows: 
13  โข  Plaintiff  Ira  Yedlin  against  Defendants  Lt.  Moore,  Sgt.  McBride,  and 
14  Grenadiers Scott, Howell, and Herr; 
15  โข  Plaintiff Janet Travis  against Defendants Lt. Moore, Sgt. McBride, and 
16  Grenadiers Turiano and Howell; and 
17  โข  Plaintiff Cynthia Guillen against Defendants Lt. Moore, Sgt. McBride, and 
18  Grenadiers Scott, Turiano, Howell, and Herr. 
19  These Plaintiffs may seek damages, including punitive damages, but not injunctive relief 
20  against these Defendants. The Court grants Defendantsโ Motion for Summary Judgment as 
21  to Plaintiffsโ Individual Claims (redacted Doc. 272, sealed Doc. 277) in all other respects. 
22    IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the Court will set a pre-trial conference by 
23  separate Order. 
24    Dated this 7th day of February, 2022. 
25   
 
 
Honorable John J. Tuchi 
26 
United States District Judge 
27 
28 
 
- 34 -

1  INTRODUCTION 
2  1.  This is a class action to enforce Plaintiffsโ fundamental constitutional 
3  rights of speech and association, and to be free from excessive police force and from 
4  discrimination and harm by law enforcement based on the content of their speech. On 
5  the night of August 22, 2017, a force of close to 900 officers of the Phoenix Police 
6  Department (โPPDโ) conducted an unannounced attack on Plaintiffs and hundreds of 
7  others  who  had  gathered  outside  the  Phoenix  Convention  Center  to  protest  in 
8  connection with a speech by President Trump; the goal of this assembly was to 
9  demonstrate strong disagreement with President Trumpโs and his supportersโ racist 
10  and anti-immigrant policies and views. Defendants knew that most, if not all, of those 
11  the police attacked were acting in a peaceable manner, but disregarded the well-being 
12  of these anti-Trump protestors as well as well-established constitutional mandates and 
13  police  policies.  PPD  personnel  indiscriminately  fired  harmful  pepper  spray,  gas, 
14  pepper bullets, and flash-bang cannisters into the assembled crowd, which included 
15  children, elderly people, disabled people, and pregnant women. The failure of the 
16  Phoenix Police to warn the peaceably assembled crowd of the coming attack, as is 
17  required by the Constitution, and to provide for a safe dispersal route for the protesters 
18  to avoid the police onslaught, guaranteed the ensuing widespread panic and fear 
19  amongst those assembled and resulted in physical and emotional injuries, as well as 
20  constitutional violations. 
21  2.   Defendant Chief of Phoenix Police Jeri L. Williams predictably had 
22  fulsome praise for the Phoenix Police personnel at the scene of the attack on the 
23  assembled crowd; as then-Mayor Greg Stanton stood by, she wholeheartedly endorsed 
24  and ratified the actions taken by Phoenix Police officers. City Manager Ed Zuercher 
25  also praised the police for their conduct at the gathering. Despite a significant increase 
26  in the Phoenix Police Departmentโs use-of-force incidents against civilians, including 
27  the events of August 22, 2017, and many other police-on-civilian shootings, City 
28  officials, including the Police Chief, the Mayor, the City Manager, and the City 
3  
 
 
 
 
 

1  Council  members  have  failed  to  condemn  this  police  violence  and  to  take  any 
2  meaningful steps to stop it, reduce it, or address the trauma that police violence causes 
3  to individuals, families, and communities in the City of Phoenix. To date in 2018, there 
4  have been thirty-seven officer-involved shootings by the Phoenix Police resulting in 
5  eighteen deaths (plus another death by taser), more than during the entire year of 2017. 
6  3.  This  action  seeks  injunctive  relief  to  restrain  the  Phoenix  Police 
7  Departmentโs use of excessive force against civilians and to prohibit future disruptions 
8  of the peaceable exercise of First Amendment rights. Absent the Courtโs intervention, 
9  those who wish to gather and speak will continue to experience understandable fear of 
10  police  retaliation  when  participating  in  protests,  demonstrations,  and  marches, 
11  particularly when expressing anti-Trump views. This action also seeks damages to 
12  compensate  Plaintiffs  and  the  class  they  represent  for  the  denial  of  their  First 
13  Amendment rights on August 22, 2017, and for the physical injuries and emotional 
14  harms resulting from the Phoenix Police Departmentโs excessive use of force. 
15  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
16  4.  This  action  arises  under  42  U.S.C.  ยง  1983  and  the  laws  and 
17  Constitution of the United States. Jurisdiction lies under 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1331, 1343, and 
18  1367. The Court has jurisdiction to issue declaratory and/or injunctive relief pursuant 
19  to 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 2201 and 2202 and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 57. The Court has 
20  authority to award attorneysโ fees under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1988(b). 
21  5.  Venue properly lies within this District under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391(b). The 
22  Defendants are all public officials or other employees or agents of the City of Phoenix, 
23  as well as the City itself. Each of the Defendants resides within this District and/or 
24  performs official duties within the State of Arizona. This Court, accordingly, has 
25  personal jurisdiction over each of the Defendants. 
26  6.  The named Defendants perform their official duties in this District, and 
27  a substantial part of the events or omissions giving rise to Plaintiffsโ claims have 
28  occurred or will occur in this District. 
4  
 
 
 
 
 

1  PARTIES 
2  Organizational Plaintiffs: Injunctive Class Representatives and Damages Plaintiffs 
3  7.  Plaintiff Puente is a grassroots nonprofit membership organization 
4  based in Phoenix, Arizona. Puenteโs mission is to develop, educate, and empower 
5  migrant communities through lobbying, advocacy, and activism. Puente provides free 
6  English classes, media trainings, know-your-rights workshops, health and wellness 
7  trainings, educational programs for children, and other services. As part of their efforts 
8  to support migrant communities, Puente members frequently organize and participate 
9  in community events and demonstrations in Phoenix. Puente members believe that the 
10  Phoenix Police Departmentโs continued unlawful use of force against organizers and 
11  protesters will deter and dissuade members and the public from participating in Puente 
12  and  community  organized  Phoenix  demonstrations  in  the  future.  Members  and 
13  supporters  of  Puente  have  been  chilled  from  participating  in  political  expressive 
14  activities by the PPDโs improper, excessive, and unconstitutional uses of force. Puente 
15  expended significant time and resources to organize and participate in the protest on 
16  August 22, 2017, to convey the message that the racist and anti-immigrant policies of 
17  the Trump administration must end; Defendantsโ actions stopped this message from 
18  reaching its intended audience. Puente members and supporters believe that they will 
19  be targeted for violent PPD retaliation if they attend future demonstrations, especially 
20  when espousing anti-Trump messages. Puente also suffered out-of-pocket damages as 
21  a result of the PPDโs unlawful actions on August 22, 2017, including for lost equipment 
22  employed at demonstrations and other events. Members were violently denied their 
23  rights to speech and association. 
24  8.  Plaintiff  Poder  in  Action  (โPoderโ)  (formerly  the  Center  for 
25  Neighborhood Leadership) is a grassroots nonprofit organization based in Phoenix, 
26  Arizona. Poderโs mission is to build power with people impacted by injustice through 
27  leadership  development,  civic  engagement,  and  policy  advocacy.  Poderโs  work 
28  includes advocacy on immigration, education, and police brutality. Poder regularly 
5  
 
 
 
 
 

1  organizes and participates in protests and political expressive activities in Phoenix to 
2  raise awareness on issues impacting black, brown, and migrant communities, including 
3  police violence. Poder representatives believe that the PPDโs continued unlawful use of 
4  force against organizers and protesters will deter and dissuade their supporters and the 
5  public  from  participating  in  such  Phoenix  protests  in  the  future.  Members  and 
6  supporters of Poder are chilled from participating in political expressive activities by 
7  the PPDโs demonstrated improper, excessive, and unconstitutional uses of force against 
8  protesters. Poder expended significant time and resources to organize and participate in 
9  the protest on August 22, 2017, to convey the message that the racist and anti-immigrant 
10  policies  of  the  Trump  administration  must  end.  Defendantsโ  actions  stopped  this 
11  message from reaching its intended audience, which included President Trump and his 
12  supporters. 
13  Injunctive and Damages Class Representatives 
14  9.  Plaintiff Janet Travis is, and was at all relevant times, a resident of 
15  downtown Phoenix. Ms. Travis attended the protest to witness first-hand and join the 
16  opposition to Trump, to document the protest, and to express her own views critical of 
17  Trumpโs policies to Trump supporters. PPD gassed Ms. Travis causing her to inhale 
18  pepper spray, and brutally shot her multiple times with unidentified projectiles in the 
19  upper back, lower back and buttocks, causing her injuries and emotional trauma so 
20  severe  she  could  not  continue  her  expressive  activities  and  had  to  seek  medical 
21  attention. Ms. Travis wants to continue to be active in political rallies and protests in 
22  her  community,  but  is  concerned  that  the  PPD  will  continue  to  target  peaceful 
23  protesters. Ms. Travis is chilled from participating in future protests and politically 
24  expressive  activities  in  Phoenix  without  significant  reform  to  the  Phoenix  Police 
25  Departmentโs policies, practices ,and procedures concerning the use of force against 
26  peaceful protesters and protecting speech and associational rights. 
27  10.  Plaintiff Ira Yedlin is a resident of Bisbee, Arizona, and a strong critic 
28  of  President  Trumpโs  politics,  policies,  and  leadership.  Mr.  Yedlin  has  attended 
6  
 
 
 
 
 

1  numerous protests since the Vietnam War and considers it his civic duty to participate 
2  in protests when he disagrees with government action. Mr. Yedlin and his wife attended 
3  the August 22, 2017 protest in Phoenix to express to Trump and his supporters their 
4  dissatisfaction with how President Trump governs the country. PPD gassed Mr. Yedlin 
5  causing  him  to  inhale  pepper  spray,  and  violently  shot  him  multiple  times  with 
6  unidentified projectiles in the face, upper torso, and leg area. PPD injured Mr. Yedlinโs 
7  face so severely that he could not continue to protest and had to seek treatment for his 
8  injuries in a hospital emergency room. Mr. Yedlin desires to continue to be active in 
9  political rallies and protests in Phoenix, but believes that the PPD will continue to target 
10  peaceful protesters. Mr. Yedlin is chilled from participating in future protests and 
11  politically expressive activities in Phoenix without significant reform to the Phoenix 
12  Police Departmentโs policies, practices, and procedures concerning the use of force 
13  against peaceful protesters and protecting speech and associational rights. 
14  11.  Plaintiff Cynthia Guillen is a resident of Mesa, Arizona, and an active 
15  participant in demonstrations in the Phoenix metropolitan area. Ms. Guillen participated 
16  in  the  demonstration  against  President  Trump  on  August  22,  2017,  to  make  her 
17  objections to this policies to his supporters. PPD gassed Ms. Guillen causing her to 
18  inhale pepper spray, and senselessly shot her in the lower stomach and hip with 
19  unidentified projectiles. The impact of PPDโs projectiles caused Ms. Guillen external 
20  and internal injuries that required her to leave the protest and seek medical attention; 
21  she has had ongoing medical treatment. Ms. Guillen is chilled from participating in 
22  future  protests  and  politically  expressive  activities  in  Phoenix  without  significant 
23  reform  to  the  Phoenix  Police  Departmentโs  policies,  practices,  and  procedures 
24  concerning the use of force against peaceful protesters and protecting speech and 
25  associational rights.  
26  12.  Plaintiff Jacinta Gonzalez Goodman is a resident of Phoenix, Arizona, 
27  and a long-time activist and organizer. Ms. Gonzalez Goodman volunteers with Puente 
28  and  works  with  Mijente,  a  national  civil  rights  organization  focused  on  building 
7  
 
 
 
 
 

1  leadership  and  social  change  in  the  Latinx  community.  Ms.  Gonzalez  Goodman 
2  participated in the demonstration against President Trump on August 22, 2017, to 
3  express her disagreement with the President and his supportersโ vision for the country, 
4  to peacefully show solidarity with her community, and to demonstrate to Trump and 
5  his supporters the intense public opposition to the Presidentโs policies and goals. Ms. 
6  Gonzalez Goodman participated in the planning of the protest, and during the protest 
7  served  as  a  liaison  between  the  protesters  and  PPD.  PPD  gassed  Ms.  Gonzalez 
8  Goodman, causing her to inhale pepper spray, which caused injuries to her lungs and 
9  eyes that lingered for a day, and forced Ms. Gonzalez Goodman to leave the protest 
10  before she could deliver her message to her intended audience. Ms. Gonzalez Goodman 
11  is chilled from participating in future protests and politically expressive activities in 
12  Phoenix  without  significant  reform  to  the  Phoenix  Police  Departmentโs  policies, 
13  practices, and procedures concerning the use of force against peaceful protesters and 
14  protecting speech and associational rights. 
15  Defendants 
16  13.  Defendant City of Phoenix is a municipal corporation, organized and 
17  existing under the laws of the State of Arizona. The Phoenix Police Department is an 
18  agency of the City of Phoenix, and all actions of the PPD are the legal responsibility of 
19  the City. 
20  14.  Defendant Jeri L. Williams is, and was at all relevant times, the Chief 
21  of Police for the City of Phoenix. As such, Chief Williams is the final policy maker for 
22  the City of Phoenix in the area of law enforcement and in setting and implementing the 
23  policies  and  practices  of  the  PPD  including  but  not  limited  to  the  development, 
24  implementation, and the training of PPD personnel in these and all PPD areas, including 
25  the procedures, policies, regulations, and practices related to the proper use of force and 
26  the need for prior warnings, in response to political protests, and public demonstrations, 
27  and marches. At all relevant times, Chief Williams was responsible for the development 
28  of policies concerning protests and the protection of participantsโ basic rights of speech 
8  
 
 
 
 
 

1  and association, for making these policies known to all PPD personnel, and for ensuring 
2  that all members of the PPD were adequately and consistently trained in their meaning 
3  and implementation, as well as in all relevant constitutional requirements and police 
4  best practices. Chief Williams was responsible for the training and preparation of PPD 
5  personnel with respect to the events of August 22, 2017, and she approved and/or 
6  ratified the PPDโs plans for that event including the unconstitutional acts complained 
7  of herein. As set out below, Chief Williams failed to establish sufficient guidelines and 
8  regulations governing the PPD in the situation presented on August 22, 2017, and did 
9  not ensure adequate training before the event, or properly supervise and monitor the 
10  actions of PPD personnel during the protest. As set out below, after becoming aware of 
11  the events and the actions of PPD on the scene, Chief Williams praised the members of 
12  the PPD with then-Mayor Stanton by her side, and fully ratified the actions of PPD 
13  personnel. City Manager Ed Zuercher also praised and ratified the PPDโs decisions and 
14  actions complained of herein. Chief Williams is sued in her official and individual 
15  capacity. 
16  15.  Defendant Benjamin Moore is a Lieutenant with the PPD. On August 
17  22, 2017, he was designated as the โAlpha Leaderโ and โField Force Commanderโ in 
18  charge of all PPD units working the night of the Trump rally and protest. Lt. Moore 
19  gave the initial improper orders for PPD officers to use force against anti-Trump 
20  protestors  that  resulted  in  indiscriminate  attacks  against  hundreds  of  peaceable 
21  protesters without warnings and before any unlawful assembly had been declared. 
22  Plaintiffs sue Lt. Moore in his official and individual capacity. 
23  16.  Defendant Douglas McBride is a Sergeant with the PPD. On August 
24  22, 2017, he was assigned as the โGrenadier Team Leaderโ for the Trump rally and 
25  protest. According to PPD, grenadiers are โspecialty trained officers on deployment of 
26  chemical munitions.โ Plaintiffs sue Sgt. McBride in his official and individual capacity. 
27  17.  Defendant Robert Scott is an officer with the PPD who was assigned 
28  to the PPDโs Tactical Response Unit as one of the โGrenadiers.โ As set forth herein, 
9  
 
 
 
 
 

1  Officer Scott indiscriminately fired on and injured Plaintiffs without warning. Plaintiffs 
2  sue Officer Scott in his official and individual capacity.

1  STATEMENT OF FACTS 
2  28.  The election of Donald J. Trump in November 2016, and his harmful 
3  policies and attitudes related to migrants, police misconduct, discrimination, women, 
4  education, health care, foreign affairs, and gun control, to name a few, have invigorated 
5  millions  of  Americans  to  join  anti-Trump  protests  and  demonstrations  in  record 
6  numbers  across  the  nation.  Overwhelming  numbers  of  protestors,  many  newly 
7  motivated by the cruel and unjustified policies of the present administration, are 
8  participating in demonstrations for the first time to express their criticism. Arizonans 
9  found themselves the target of Trumpโs racist and anti-immigrant politics when, in the 
10  summer of 2017, he publicized his intent to pardon former Sheriff Joe Arpaio, who 
11  had been convicted of criminal contempt of court after disobeying a federal judgeโs 
12  order to end the practice of racial profiling and detaining persons suspected of being 
13  in the United States unlawfully solely based on their perceived Latino race. When 
14  Trump announced plans to speak in Phoenix just before his anticipated pardon of 
15  Arpaio (who is widely known for visiting indignities on prisoners and terrorizing 
16  immigrant communities in Maricopa County), Arizonans planned to take to the streets. 
17  Plans to Demonstrate in Quintessential Public Fora 
18  29.  On August 16, 2017, Trumpโs campaign announced that he would 
19  deliver a speech at a campaign-style rally at the Phoenix Convention Center less than a 
20  week later. This announcement came on the heels of a violent clash between two groups 
21  of  demonstrators  in  Charlottesville,  Virginia,  one  group  consisting  of  white 
22  supremacists and one group consisting of pro-social-justice advocates. One woman was 
23  killed by the intentional act of a white supremacist, and several were injured in the 
24  clashes in Charlottesville. Trump reacted to the events in Charlottesville by proclaiming 
25  that there were โgood peopleโ on both sides. 
26  30.  With the events of Charlottesville in mind, Plaintiffs Puente and Poder 
27  in Action, and other activists and groups, mobilized to plan a safe protest before and 
28  after Trumpโs rally scheduled for early evening on August 22, 2017 (โTrump Protestโ). 
12

4  be  able  to  safely  exercise  their  free-speech  and  assembly  rights,  and  make  their 
5  opposition to Trumpโs actions known to his supporters. Puente, Poder, and other

5  to ensure that official policy was changed and officers were trained in a manner 
6  sufficient to address the practice and custom to violate First and Fourth Amendment 
7  rights. 
8  101.  PPD policy directs that bean bags should not be fired at closer than 
9  five feet and that the lower torso, legs, and buttocks should be the primary targets. The 
10  PPD policy on bean bags prohibits hitting the head, neck, and spine and warns that 
11  โshots to non-target areasโ (head, neck, spine, thorax, and spine) โcan result in fatal or 
12  serious injury.โ 
13  102.  As for the use of pepper spray, PPD policy specifically orders, โDo 
14  not use within three (3) feet of a subject as soft tissue damage could occur.โ (Emphasis 
15  in policy.)  
16  103.  PPD policy is silent on what officers and command staff must do to 
17  ensure that police warnings prior to dispersal are given and heard. Despite the legal 
18  necessity of prior warnings, the policy provides no guidance on what warnings or 
19  dispersal instructions must be given to protestors exercising their First Amendment 
20  rights.  
21  104.  Additionally,  PPD  policy  does  not  restrict  the  use  of  less-lethal 
22  munitions on already dispersing crowds or individuals, and crowds that are retreating, 
23  nor or on persons who are using recording devices to lawfully document public police 
24  actions.  
25  105.  The failure to maintain adequate policies, and to regularly train PPD 
26  personnel on these and proper crowd control, led to the injuries suffered by Plaintiffs. 
27  The need for training in this instance was obvious.
